+{"mobileview":{"lastmodified":"2014-10-14T05:11:42Z","lastmodifiedby":{"name":"Carlossuarez46","gender":"unknown"},"id":49728,"languagecount":141,"displaytitle":"San Francisco","sections":[{"toclevel":1,"level":"2","line":"History","number":"1","index":"1","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"History","id":1,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a href=\"/wiki/History_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"History of San Francisco\">History of San Francisco</a></div>\n<div class=\"hatnote boilerplate seealso\">See also: <a href=\"/wiki/Timeline_of_San_Francisco_history\" title=\"Timeline of San Francisco history\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Timeline of San Francisco history</a></div>\n<div class=\"quotebox\" style=\"float: left; clear: left; margin: 0.5em 1.4em 0.8em 0; width: 18.75em; padding: 6px; border: 1px solid #aaa; font-size: 90%; background-color: #B0C4DE;\">\n<div class=\"\" style=\"background-color: #B0C4DE; color: black; text-align: center; font-size: larger; font-weight: bold;\">Historical Affiliations</div>\n<div class=\"\" style=\"position: relative; text-align: left;\">\n<div>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Spanish_Empire\" title=\"Spanish Empire\">Spanish Empire</a> 1776\u20131821<br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/First_Mexican_Empire\" title=\"First Mexican Empire\">First Mexican Empire</a> 1821\u20131823<br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/First_Mexican_Republic\" title=\"First Mexican Republic\">United Mexican States</a> 1823\u20131835<br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/Centralist_Republic_of_Mexico\" title=\"Centralist Republic of Mexico\">Mexican Republic</a> 1835\u20131848<br />\n<a href=\"/wiki/United_States\" title=\"United States\">United States</a> 1848\u2013present</p>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div style=\"text-align: left;\"></div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Mission_San_Francisco_de_Asis_old.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Mission_San_Francisco_de_Asis_old.jpg/220px-Mission_San_Francisco_de_Asis_old.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"176\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8f/Mission_San_Francisco_de_Asis_old.jpg/330px-Mission_San_Francisco_de_Asis_old.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/8/8f/Mission_San_Francisco_de_Asis_old.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"365\" data-file-height=\"292\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Mission_San_Francisco_de_Asis_old.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\n<a href=\"/wiki/Mission_San_Francisco_de_As%C3%ADs\" title=\"Mission San Francisco de As\u00eds\">Mission San Francisco de As\u00eds</a> (Mission Dolores)</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The earliest archaeological evidence of human habitation of the territory of the city of San Francisco dates to 3000&#160;BC.<sup id=\"cite_ref-25\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-25\"><span>[</span>25<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/Yelamu\" title=\"Yelamu\">Yelamu</a> group of the <a href=\"/wiki/Ohlone\" title=\"Ohlone\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Ohlone</a> people resided in a few small villages when an overland <a href=\"/wiki/Spanish_colonization_of_the_Americas\" title=\"Spanish colonization of the Americas\">Spanish exploration party</a>, led by Don <a href=\"/wiki/Gaspar_de_Portol%C3%A0\" title=\"Gaspar de Portol\u00e0\">Gaspar de Portol\u00e0</a> arrived on November 2, 1769, the first documented European visit to <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay\" title=\"San Francisco Bay\">San Francisco Bay</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Portola_26-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Portola-26\"><span>[</span>26<span>]</span></a></sup> Seven years later, on March 28, 1776, the Spanish established the <a href=\"/wiki/Presidio_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Presidio of San Francisco\">Presidio of San Francisco</a>, followed by a <a href=\"/wiki/Spanish_Missions_of_California\" title=\"Spanish Missions of California\" class=\"mw-redirect\">mission</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_San_Francisco_de_As%C3%ADs\" title=\"Mission San Francisco de As\u00eds\">Mission San Francisco de As\u00eds</a> (Mission Dolores), established by the Spanish explorer <a href=\"/wiki/Juan_Bautista_de_Anza\" title=\"Juan Bautista de Anza\">Juan Bautista de Anza</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-DeAnza-Moraga-Palou_20-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-DeAnza-Moraga-Palou-20\"><span>[</span>20<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>Upon <a href=\"/wiki/Mexican_War_of_Independence\" title=\"Mexican War of Independence\">independence</a> from Spain in 1821, the area became part of <a href=\"/wiki/Mexico\" title=\"Mexico\">Mexico</a>. Under Mexican rule, the mission system gradually ended, and its lands became <a href=\"/wiki/Ranchos_of_California\" title=\"Ranchos of California\">privatized</a>. In 1835, Englishman <a href=\"/wiki/William_A._Richardson\" title=\"William A. Richardson\">William Richardson</a> erected the first independent homestead,<sup id=\"cite_ref-Richardson_27-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Richardson-27\"><span>[</span>27<span>]</span></a></sup> near a boat anchorage around what is today <a href=\"/wiki/Portsmouth_Square\" title=\"Portsmouth Square\">Portsmouth Square</a>. Together with <a href=\"/wiki/Alcalde\" title=\"Alcalde\">Alcalde</a> <a href=\"/wiki/Francisco_de_Haro\" title=\"Francisco de Haro\">Francisco de Haro</a>, he laid out a street plan for the expanded settlement, and the town, named <a href=\"/wiki/Yerba_Buena,_California\" title=\"Yerba Buena, California\">Yerba Buena</a>, began to attract American settlers. Commodore <a href=\"/wiki/John_D._Sloat\" title=\"John D. Sloat\">John D. Sloat</a> claimed California for the United States on July 7, 1846, during the <a href=\"/wiki/Mexican-American_War\" title=\"Mexican-American War\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Mexican-American War</a>, and Captain <a href=\"/wiki/John_B._Montgomery\" title=\"John B. Montgomery\">John B. Montgomery</a> arrived to claim Yerba Buena two days later. Yerba Buena was renamed San Francisco on January 30 of the next year,<sup id=\"cite_ref-28\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-28\"><span>[</span>28<span>]</span></a></sup> and Mexico officially <a href=\"/wiki/Mexican_Cession\" title=\"Mexican Cession\">ceded the territory</a> to the United States at the <a href=\"/wiki/Treaty_of_Guadalupe-Hidalgo\" title=\"Treaty of Guadalupe-Hidalgo\" class=\"mw-redirect\">end of the war</a>. Despite its attractive location as a port and naval base, San Francisco was still a small settlement with inhospitable geography.<sup id=\"cite_ref-29\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-29\"><span>[</span>29<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Francis_Samuel_Marryat,_San_Francisco,_lithograph.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Francis_Samuel_Marryat%2C_San_Francisco%2C_lithograph.jpg/220px-Francis_Samuel_Marryat%2C_San_Francisco%2C_lithograph.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"156\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Francis_Samuel_Marryat%2C_San_Francisco%2C_lithograph.jpg/330px-Francis_Samuel_Marryat%2C_San_Francisco%2C_lithograph.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/75/Francis_Samuel_Marryat%2C_San_Francisco%2C_lithograph.jpg/440px-Francis_Samuel_Marryat%2C_San_Francisco%2C_lithograph.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"3284\" data-file-height=\"2324\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Francis_Samuel_Marryat,_San_Francisco,_lithograph.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nFrancis Samuel Marryat, <i>Hilltop of San Francisco, California, Looking toward the Bay</i>, 1849. M.&amp; N. Hanhart Chromolithograph</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SanFranciscoharbor1851c_sharp.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/SanFranciscoharbor1851c_sharp.jpg/220px-SanFranciscoharbor1851c_sharp.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"148\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/SanFranciscoharbor1851c_sharp.jpg/330px-SanFranciscoharbor1851c_sharp.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/46/SanFranciscoharbor1851c_sharp.jpg/440px-SanFranciscoharbor1851c_sharp.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"2574\" data-file-height=\"1727\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SanFranciscoharbor1851c_sharp.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\n<a href=\"/wiki/Port_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Port of San Francisco\">Port of San Francisco</a> in 1851</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The <a href=\"/wiki/California_Gold_Rush\" title=\"California Gold Rush\">California Gold Rush</a> brought a flood of treasure seekers. With their <a href=\"/wiki/Sourdough\" title=\"Sourdough\">sourdough bread</a> in tow,<sup id=\"cite_ref-30\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-30\"><span>[</span>30<span>]</span></a></sup> prospectors accumulated in San Francisco over rival <a href=\"/wiki/Benicia,_California\" title=\"Benicia, California\">Benicia</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-31\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-31\"><span>[</span>31<span>]</span></a></sup> raising the population from 1,000 in 1848 to 25,000 by December 1849.<sup id=\"cite_ref-1849pop_32-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-1849pop-32\"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup> The promise of fabulous riches was so strong that crews on arriving vessels deserted and rushed off to the gold fields, leaving behind a forest of masts in San Francisco harbor.<sup id=\"cite_ref-buriedships_33-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-buriedships-33\"><span>[</span>33<span>]</span></a></sup> California was quickly <a href=\"/wiki/Compromise_of_1850\" title=\"Compromise of 1850\">granted statehood</a>, and the U.S. military built <a href=\"/wiki/Fort_Point,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Fort Point, San Francisco\">Fort Point</a> at the <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate\" title=\"Golden Gate\">Golden Gate</a> and a fort on <a href=\"/wiki/Alcatraz_Island\" title=\"Alcatraz Island\">Alcatraz Island</a> to secure the San Francisco Bay. Silver discoveries, including the <a href=\"/wiki/Comstock_Lode\" title=\"Comstock Lode\">Comstock Lode</a> in 1859, further drove rapid population growth.<sup id=\"cite_ref-34\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-34\"><span>[</span>34<span>]</span></a></sup> With hordes of fortune seekers streaming through the city, lawlessness was common, and the <a href=\"/wiki/Barbary_Coast,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Barbary Coast, San Francisco\">Barbary Coast</a> section of town gained notoriety as a haven for criminals, prostitution, and gambling.<sup id=\"cite_ref-35\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-35\"><span>[</span>35<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>Entrepreneurs sought to capitalize on the wealth generated by the Gold Rush. Early winners were the banking industry, with the founding of <a href=\"/wiki/Wells_Fargo\" title=\"Wells Fargo\">Wells Fargo</a> in 1852 and the <a href=\"/wiki/Bank_of_California\" title=\"Bank of California\">Bank of California</a> in 1864. Development of the <a href=\"/wiki/Port_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Port of San Francisco\">Port of San Francisco</a> and the establishment in 1869 of overland access to the Eastern U.S. rail system via the newly completed <a href=\"/wiki/First_Transcontinental_Railroad\" title=\"First Transcontinental Railroad\">Pacific Railroad</a> (the construction of which the city only reluctantly helped support<sup id=\"cite_ref-36\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-36\"><span>[</span>36<span>]</span></a></sup>) helped make the Bay Area a center for trade. Catering to the needs and tastes of the growing population, <a href=\"/wiki/Levi_Strauss\" title=\"Levi Strauss\">Levi Strauss</a> opened a dry goods business and <a href=\"/wiki/Domingo_Ghirardelli\" title=\"Domingo Ghirardelli\">Domingo Ghirardelli</a> began manufacturing chocolate. Immigrant laborers made the city a polyglot culture, with <a href=\"/wiki/Chinese_Railroad_Workers\" title=\"Chinese Railroad Workers\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Chinese railroad workers</a> creating the city's <a href=\"/wiki/Chinatown,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Chinatown, San Francisco\">Chinatown</a> quarter. In 1870, Asians made up 8% of the population.<sup id=\"cite_ref-census_37-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-census-37\"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> The first <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_cable_car_system\" title=\"San Francisco cable car system\">cable cars</a> carried San Franciscans up <a href=\"/wiki/Clay_Street_Hill_Railroad\" title=\"Clay Street Hill Railroad\">Clay Street</a> in 1873. The city's sea of <a href=\"/wiki/Victorian_house\" title=\"Victorian house\">Victorian houses</a> began to take shape, and civic leaders campaigned for a spacious public park, resulting in plans for <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_Park\" title=\"Golden Gate Park\">Golden Gate Park</a>. San Franciscans built schools, churches, theaters, and all the hallmarks of civic life. The <a href=\"/wiki/Presidio_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Presidio of San Francisco\">Presidio</a> developed into the most important American military installation on the Pacific coast.<sup id=\"cite_ref-38\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-38\"><span>[</span>38<span>]</span></a></sup> By 1890, San Francisco's population approached 300,000, making it the <a href=\"/wiki/Largest_cities_in_the_United_States_by_population_by_decade#1890\" title=\"Largest cities in the United States by population by decade\">eighth-largest city</a> in the U.S. at the time. Around 1901, San Francisco was a major city known for its flamboyant style, stately hotels, ostentatious mansions on <a href=\"/wiki/Nob_Hill,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Nob Hill, San Francisco\">Nob Hill</a>, and a thriving arts scene.<sup id=\"cite_ref-39\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-39\"><span>[</span>39<span>]</span></a></sup> The first North American plague epidemic was the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_plague_of_1900%E2%80%931904\" title=\"San Francisco plague of 1900\u20131904\" class=\"mw-redirect\">San Francisco plague of 1900\u20131904</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-40\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-40\"><span>[</span>40<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>At 5:12&#160;am on April 18, 1906, a major <a href=\"/wiki/1906_San_Francisco_earthquake\" title=\"1906 San Francisco earthquake\">earthquake struck San Francisco</a> and northern California. As buildings collapsed from the shaking, ruptured gas lines ignited fires that spread across the city and burned out of control for several days. With water mains out of service, the <a href=\"/wiki/Presidio_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Presidio of San Francisco\">Presidio</a> Artillery Corps attempted to contain the inferno by dynamiting blocks of buildings to create firebreaks.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Funston_41-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Funston-41\"><span>[</span>41<span>]</span></a></sup> More than three-quarters of the city lay in ruins, including almost all of the downtown core.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Montagne_22-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Montagne-22\"><span>[</span>22<span>]</span></a></sup> Contemporary accounts reported that 498 people lost their lives, though modern estimates put the number in the several thousands.<sup id=\"cite_ref-42\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-42\"><span>[</span>42<span>]</span></a></sup> More than half of the city's population of 400,000 was left homeless.<sup id=\"cite_ref-43\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-43\"><span>[</span>43<span>]</span></a></sup> Refugees settled temporarily in makeshift tent villages in Golden Gate Park, the Presidio, on the beaches, and elsewhere. Many fled permanently to the <a href=\"/wiki/East_Bay_(San_Francisco_Bay_Area)\" title=\"East Bay (San Francisco Bay Area)\">East Bay</a>.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tnone\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; width:; max-width:1408px;\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\">\n<div class=\"overflowbugx\" style=\"overflow:auto;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:San_francisco_fire_1906.jpg\" class=\"image\" title=\"&quot;Not in history has a modern imperial city been so completely destroyed. San Francisco is gone.&quot; \u2013Jack London after the 1906 earthquake and fire[44]\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/3/3e/San_francisco_fire_1906.jpg\" width=\"1400\" height=\"311\" data-file-width=\"936\" data-file-height=\"208\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:San_francisco_fire_1906.jpg\" title=\"File:San francisco fire 1906.jpg\"></a></div>\n\"Not in history has a modern imperial city been so completely destroyed. San Francisco is gone.\" \u2013<a href=\"/wiki/Jack_London\" title=\"Jack London\">Jack London</a> after the <a href=\"/wiki/1906_San_Francisco_earthquake\" title=\"1906 San Francisco earthquake\">1906 earthquake</a> and fire<sup id=\"cite_ref-44\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-44\"><span>[</span>44<span>]</span></a></sup></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:PalaceofFineArts1915.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/PalaceofFineArts1915.jpg/220px-PalaceofFineArts1915.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"155\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/PalaceofFineArts1915.jpg/330px-PalaceofFineArts1915.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9d/PalaceofFineArts1915.jpg/440px-PalaceofFineArts1915.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"704\" data-file-height=\"496\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:PalaceofFineArts1915.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe <a href=\"/wiki/Palace_of_Fine_Arts\" title=\"Palace of Fine Arts\">Palace of Fine Arts</a> at the 1915 <a href=\"/wiki/Panama-Pacific_International_Exposition_(1915)\" title=\"Panama-Pacific International Exposition (1915)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Panama-Pacific Exposition</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Rebuilding was rapid and performed on a grand scale. Rejecting calls to completely remake the street grid, San Franciscans opted for speed.<sup id=\"cite_ref-NatTrust1_45-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-NatTrust1-45\"><span>[</span>45<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Amadeo_Giannini\" title=\"Amadeo Giannini\">Amadeo Giannini</a>'s <a href=\"/wiki/Bank_of_Italy_(USA)\" title=\"Bank of Italy (USA)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Bank of Italy</a>, later to become <a href=\"/wiki/Bank_of_America\" title=\"Bank of America\">Bank of America</a>, provided loans for many of those whose livelihoods had been devastated. The influential <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Planning_and_Urban_Research_Association\" title=\"San Francisco Planning and Urban Research Association\">San Francisco Planning and Urban Research Association</a> or SPUR was founded in 1910 to address the quality of housing after the earthquake.<sup id=\"cite_ref-46\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-46\"><span>[</span>46<span>]</span></a></sup> The earthquake hastened development of western neighborhoods that survived the fire, including <a href=\"/wiki/Pacific_Heights,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Pacific Heights, San Francisco\">Pacific Heights</a>, where many of the city's wealthy rebuilt their homes.<sup id=\"cite_ref-47\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-47\"><span>[</span>47<span>]</span></a></sup> In turn, the destroyed mansions of Nob Hill became grand hotels. <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_City_Hall\" title=\"San Francisco City Hall\">City Hall</a> rose again in splendorous <a href=\"/wiki/Beaux-Arts_architecture\" title=\"Beaux-Arts architecture\">Beaux Arts</a> style, and the city celebrated its rebirth at the <a href=\"/wiki/Panama-Pacific_International_Exposition_(1915)\" title=\"Panama-Pacific International Exposition (1915)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Panama-Pacific International Exposition</a> in 1915.<sup id=\"cite_ref-48\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-48\"><span>[</span>48<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>It was during this period San Francisco built some of its most important infrastructure. Civil Engineer <a href=\"/wiki/Michael_O%27Shaughnessy\" title=\"Michael O'Shaughnessy\">Michael O'Shaughnessy</a> was hired by San Francisco Mayor <a href=\"/wiki/James_Rolph\" title=\"James Rolph\">James Rolph</a> as chief engineer for the city in September 1912 to supervise the construction of the Twin Peaks Reservoir, the <a href=\"/wiki/Stockton_Street_Tunnel\" title=\"Stockton Street Tunnel\">Stockton Street Tunnel</a>, the <a href=\"/wiki/Twin_Peaks_Tunnel\" title=\"Twin Peaks Tunnel\">Twin Peaks Tunnel</a>, the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Municipal_Railway\" title=\"San Francisco Municipal Railway\">San Francisco Municipal Railway</a>, the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Fire_Department_Auxiliary_Water_Supply_System\" title=\"San Francisco Fire Department Auxiliary Water Supply System\">Auxiliary Water Supply System</a>, and new sewers. San Francisco's streetcar system, of which the J, K, L, M, and N lines survive today, was pushed to completion by O'Shaughnessy between 1915 and 1927. It was the <a href=\"/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy\" title=\"Hetch Hetchy\">O'Shaughnessy Dam</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy_Reservoir\" title=\"Hetch Hetchy Reservoir\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Hetch Hetchy Reservoir</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy_Aqueduct\" title=\"Hetch Hetchy Aqueduct\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Hetch Hetchy Aqueduct</a> that would have the largest effect on San Francisco.<sup id=\"cite_ref-49\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-49\"><span>[</span>49<span>]</span></a></sup> An abundant water supply enabled San Francisco to develop into the city it has become today.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SF-Oakland-Bay-Bridge-Construction.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/SF-Oakland-Bay-Bridge-Construction.jpg/220px-SF-Oakland-Bay-Bridge-Construction.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"147\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/SF-Oakland-Bay-Bridge-Construction.jpg/330px-SF-Oakland-Bay-Bridge-Construction.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/b/bf/SF-Oakland-Bay-Bridge-Construction.jpg/440px-SF-Oakland-Bay-Bridge-Construction.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"768\" data-file-height=\"512\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SF-Oakland-Bay-Bridge-Construction.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco%E2%80%93Oakland_Bay_Bridge\" title=\"San Francisco\u2013Oakland Bay Bridge\">Bay Bridge</a>, under construction in 1935, took forty months to complete.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>In ensuing years, the city solidified its standing as a financial capital; in the wake of the <a href=\"/wiki/Wall_Street_Crash_of_1929\" title=\"Wall Street Crash of 1929\">1929 stock market crash</a>, not a single San Francisco-based bank failed.<sup id=\"cite_ref-50\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-50\"><span>[</span>50<span>]</span></a></sup> Indeed, it was at the height of the <a href=\"/wiki/Great_Depression\" title=\"Great Depression\">Great Depression</a> that San Francisco undertook two great civil engineering projects, simultaneously constructing the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_%E2%80%93_Oakland_Bay_Bridge\" title=\"San Francisco \u2013 Oakland Bay Bridge\" class=\"mw-redirect\">San Francisco \u2013 Oakland Bay Bridge</a> and the <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_Bridge\" title=\"Golden Gate Bridge\">Golden Gate Bridge</a>, completing them in 1936 and 1937 respectively. It was in this period that the island of <a href=\"/wiki/Alcatraz_Island\" title=\"Alcatraz Island\">Alcatraz</a>, a former military stockade, began its service as a federal maximum security prison, housing notorious inmates such as <a href=\"/wiki/Al_Capone\" title=\"Al Capone\">Al Capone</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Robert_Franklin_Stroud\" title=\"Robert Franklin Stroud\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Robert Franklin Stroud</a>, The Birdman of Alcatraz. San Francisco later celebrated its regained grandeur with a <a href=\"/wiki/World%27s_fair\" title=\"World's fair\">World's Fair</a>, the <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_International_Exposition\" title=\"Golden Gate International Exposition\">Golden Gate International Exposition</a> in 1939\u201340, creating <a href=\"/wiki/Treasure_Island_(California)\" title=\"Treasure Island (California)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Treasure Island</a> in the middle of the bay to house it.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:172px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:USS_San_Francisco_(CA-38)_enters_San_Francisco_Bay,_December_1942.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/USS_San_Francisco_%28CA-38%29_enters_San_Francisco_Bay%2C_December_1942.jpg/170px-USS_San_Francisco_%28CA-38%29_enters_San_Francisco_Bay%2C_December_1942.jpg\" width=\"170\" height=\"214\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/USS_San_Francisco_%28CA-38%29_enters_San_Francisco_Bay%2C_December_1942.jpg/255px-USS_San_Francisco_%28CA-38%29_enters_San_Francisco_Bay%2C_December_1942.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/USS_San_Francisco_%28CA-38%29_enters_San_Francisco_Bay%2C_December_1942.jpg/340px-USS_San_Francisco_%28CA-38%29_enters_San_Francisco_Bay%2C_December_1942.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"590\" data-file-height=\"743\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:USS_San_Francisco_(CA-38)_enters_San_Francisco_Bay,_December_1942.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe <a href=\"/wiki/USS_San_Francisco_(CA-38)\" title=\"USS San Francisco (CA-38)\">USS <i>San Francisco</i></a> steams under the <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_Bridge\" title=\"Golden Gate Bridge\">Golden Gate Bridge</a> in 1942, during World War&#160;II.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>During World War II, the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Naval_Shipyard\" title=\"San Francisco Naval Shipyard\">Hunters Point Naval Shipyard</a> became a hub of activity, and <a href=\"/wiki/Fort_Mason\" title=\"Fort Mason\">Fort Mason</a> became the primary port of embarkation for service members shipping out to the <a href=\"/wiki/Pacific_Theater_of_Operations\" title=\"Pacific Theater of Operations\">Pacific Theater of Operations</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-WWII_23-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-WWII-23\"><span>[</span>23<span>]</span></a></sup> The explosion of jobs drew many people, especially African Americans <a href=\"/wiki/Second_Great_Migration_(African_American)\" title=\"Second Great Migration (African American)\">from the South</a>, to the area. After the end of the war, many military personnel returning from service abroad and civilians who had originally come to work decided to stay. The <a href=\"/wiki/United_Nations_Charter\" title=\"United Nations Charter\">UN Charter</a> creating the UN was drafted and signed in San Francisco in 1945 and, in 1951, the <a href=\"/wiki/Treaty_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Treaty of San Francisco\">Treaty of San Francisco</a> officially ended the <a href=\"/wiki/Pacific_War\" title=\"Pacific War\">war with Japan</a>.</p>\n<p>Urban planning projects in the 1950s and 1960s involved widespread destruction and redevelopment of west-side neighborhoods and the construction of new freeways, of which only a series of short segments were built before being halted by <a href=\"/wiki/Freeway_and_expressway_revolts#San_Francisco\" title=\"Freeway and expressway revolts\" class=\"mw-redirect\">citizen-led opposition</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-51\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-51\"><span>[</span>51<span>]</span></a></sup> The onset of <a href=\"/wiki/Containerization\" title=\"Containerization\">containerization</a> made San Francisco's small piers obsolete, and cargo activity moved to the larger <a href=\"/wiki/Port_of_Oakland\" title=\"Port of Oakland\">Port of Oakland</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-52\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-52\"><span>[</span>52<span>]</span></a></sup> The city began to lose industrial jobs and turned to tourism as the most important segment of its economy.<sup id=\"cite_ref-53\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-53\"><span>[</span>53<span>]</span></a></sup> The suburbs experienced rapid growth, and San Francisco underwent significant demographic change, as large segments of the white population left the city, supplanted by an increasing wave of <a href=\"/wiki/Immigration_to_the_United_States\" title=\"Immigration to the United States\">immigration</a> from Asia and Latin America.<sup id=\"cite_ref-54\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-54\"><span>[</span>54<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-55\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-55\"><span>[</span>55<span>]</span></a></sup> From 1950 to 1980, the city lost over 10 percent of its population.</p>\n<p>Over this period, San Francisco became a magnet for America's <a href=\"/wiki/Counterculture\" title=\"Counterculture\">counterculture</a>. <a href=\"/wiki/Beat_Generation\" title=\"Beat Generation\">Beat Generation</a> writers fueled the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Renaissance\" title=\"San Francisco Renaissance\">San Francisco Renaissance</a> and centered on the <a href=\"/wiki/North_Beach,_San_Francisco\" title=\"North Beach, San Francisco\">North Beach</a> neighborhood in the 1950s.<sup id=\"cite_ref-56\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-56\"><span>[</span>56<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Hippie\" title=\"Hippie\">Hippies</a> flocked to <a href=\"/wiki/Haight-Ashbury\" title=\"Haight-Ashbury\">Haight-Ashbury</a> in the 1960s, reaching a peak with the 1967 <a href=\"/wiki/Summer_of_Love\" title=\"Summer of Love\">Summer of Love</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-57\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-57\"><span>[</span>57<span>]</span></a></sup> In 1974, the <a href=\"/wiki/Zebra_murders\" title=\"Zebra murders\">Zebra murders</a> left at least 16 people dead.<sup id=\"cite_ref-58\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-58\"><span>[</span>58<span>]</span></a></sup> In the 1970s, the city became a center of the <a href=\"/wiki/LGBT_social_movements\" title=\"LGBT social movements\">gay rights movement</a>, with the emergence of <a href=\"/wiki/The_Castro,_San_Francisco\" title=\"The Castro, San Francisco\">The Castro</a> as an urban <a href=\"/wiki/Gay_village\" title=\"Gay village\">gay village</a>, the election of <a href=\"/wiki/Harvey_Milk\" title=\"Harvey Milk\">Harvey Milk</a> to the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Board_of_Supervisors\" title=\"San Francisco Board of Supervisors\">Board of Supervisors</a>, and his <a href=\"/wiki/Moscone-Milk_assassinations\" title=\"Moscone-Milk assassinations\" class=\"mw-redirect\">assassination</a>, along with that of Mayor <a href=\"/wiki/George_Moscone\" title=\"George Moscone\">George Moscone</a>, in 1978.<sup id=\"cite_ref-59\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-59\"><span>[</span>59<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>Bank of America completed <a href=\"/wiki/555_California_Street\" title=\"555 California Street\">555 California Street</a> in 1969 and the <a href=\"/wiki/Transamerica_Pyramid\" title=\"Transamerica Pyramid\">Transamerica Pyramid</a> was completed in 1972,<sup id=\"cite_ref-60\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-60\"><span>[</span>60<span>]</span></a></sup> igniting a wave of \"<a href=\"/wiki/Manhattanization\" title=\"Manhattanization\">Manhattanization</a>\" that lasted until the late 1980s, a period of extensive high-rise development downtown.<sup id=\"cite_ref-NatTrust2_61-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-NatTrust2-61\"><span>[</span>61<span>]</span></a></sup> The 1980s also saw a dramatic increase in the number of homeless people in the city, an issue that remains today, despite many attempts to address it.<sup id=\"cite_ref-62\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-62\"><span>[</span>62<span>]</span></a></sup> The 1989 <a href=\"/wiki/Loma_Prieta_earthquake\" title=\"Loma Prieta earthquake\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Loma Prieta earthquake</a> caused destruction and loss of life throughout the Bay Area. In San Francisco, the quake severely damaged structures in the <a href=\"/wiki/Marina_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Marina District, San Francisco\">Marina</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/South_of_Market,_San_Francisco\" title=\"South of Market, San Francisco\">South of Market</a> districts and precipitated the demolition of the damaged <a href=\"/wiki/California_State_Route_480\" title=\"California State Route 480\">Embarcadero Freeway</a> and much of the damaged <a href=\"/wiki/Central_Freeway\" title=\"Central Freeway\">Central Freeway</a>, allowing the city to reclaim its historic downtown <a href=\"/wiki/Embarcadero_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Embarcadero (San Francisco)\">The Embarcadero</a> waterfront and revitalizing the <a href=\"/wiki/Hayes_Valley,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Hayes Valley, San Francisco\">Hayes Valley</a> neighborhood.</p>\n<p>The last 20 years have seen two booms driven by the internet industry. First was the <a href=\"/wiki/Dot-com_bubble\" title=\"Dot-com bubble\">dot-com boom</a> of the late 1990s, <a href=\"/wiki/Startup_company\" title=\"Startup company\">startup companies</a> invigorated the San Francisco economy. Large numbers of entrepreneurs and computer application developers moved into the city, followed by marketing, design, and sales professionals, changing the social landscape as once-poorer neighborhoods became increasingly <a href=\"/wiki/Gentrification\" title=\"Gentrification\">gentrified</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-63\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-63\"><span>[</span>63<span>]</span></a></sup> Demand for new housing and office space ignited a second wave of high-rise development, this time South of Market.<sup id=\"cite_ref-64\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-64\"><span>[</span>64<span>]</span></a></sup> By 2000, the city's population reached new highs, surpassing the previous record set in 1950. When the bubble burst in 2001, many of these companies folded and their employees were laid off. Yet high technology and entrepreneurship remain mainstays of the San Francisco economy. By the mid 2000s, the <a href=\"/wiki/Web_2.0\" title=\"Web 2.0\">social media boom</a> had begun, with San Francisco becoming a popular location for tech offices and also a popular <a href=\"/wiki/Bedroom_community\" title=\"Bedroom community\" class=\"mw-redirect\">bedroom community</a> for major employers in <a href=\"/wiki/Silicon_Valley\" title=\"Silicon Valley\">Silicon Valley</a> such as <a href=\"/wiki/Google\" title=\"Google\">Google</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-65\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-65\"><span>[</span>65<span>]</span></a></sup></p>"},{"toclevel":1,"level":"2","line":"Geography","number":"2","index":"2","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Geography","id":2,"text":"<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:172px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SanFranciscoFromTheISS(Cropped).jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/SanFranciscoFromTheISS%28Cropped%29.jpg/170px-SanFranciscoFromTheISS%28Cropped%29.jpg\" width=\"170\" height=\"291\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/SanFranciscoFromTheISS%28Cropped%29.jpg/255px-SanFranciscoFromTheISS%28Cropped%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7f/SanFranciscoFromTheISS%28Cropped%29.jpg/340px-SanFranciscoFromTheISS%28Cropped%29.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"389\" data-file-height=\"667\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SanFranciscoFromTheISS(Cropped).jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe San Francisco Peninsula</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>San Francisco is located on the <a href=\"/wiki/West_Coast_of_the_United_States\" title=\"West Coast of the United States\">West Coast of the United States</a> at the north end of the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Peninsula\" title=\"San Francisco Peninsula\">San Francisco Peninsula</a> and includes significant stretches of the Pacific Ocean and <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay\" title=\"San Francisco Bay\">San Francisco Bay</a> within its boundaries. Several picturesque <a href=\"/wiki/Islands_of_San_Francisco_Bay\" title=\"Islands of San Francisco Bay\" class=\"mw-redirect\">islands</a>\u2014<a href=\"/wiki/Alcatraz_Island\" title=\"Alcatraz Island\">Alcatraz</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Treasure_Island,_California\" title=\"Treasure Island, California\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Treasure Island</a> and the adjacent <a href=\"/wiki/Yerba_Buena_Island\" title=\"Yerba Buena Island\">Yerba Buena Island</a>, and small portions of <a href=\"/wiki/Alameda_(island)\" title=\"Alameda (island)\">Alameda Island</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Red_Rock_Island\" title=\"Red Rock Island\">Red Rock Island</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Angel_Island,_California\" title=\"Angel Island, California\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Angel Island</a>\u2014are part of the city. Also included are the uninhabited <a href=\"/wiki/Farallon_Islands\" title=\"Farallon Islands\">Farallon Islands</a>, 27 miles (43&#160;km) offshore in the Pacific Ocean. The mainland within the city limits roughly forms a \"seven-by-seven-mile square,\" a common local colloquialism referring to the city's shape, though its total area, including water, is nearly 232 square miles (600&#160;km<sup>2</sup>).</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:172px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Lombardst.jpeg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Lombardst.jpeg/170px-Lombardst.jpeg\" width=\"170\" height=\"227\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Lombardst.jpeg/255px-Lombardst.jpeg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/d/da/Lombardst.jpeg/340px-Lombardst.jpeg 2x\" data-file-width=\"960\" data-file-height=\"1280\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Lombardst.jpeg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nCars navigate <a href=\"/wiki/Lombard_Street_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Lombard Street (San Francisco)\">Lombard Street</a> to descend <a href=\"/wiki/Russian_Hill,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Russian Hill, San Francisco\">Russian Hill</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>There are more than 50 hills within city limits.<sup id=\"cite_ref-peak_experience_66-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-peak_experience-66\"><span>[</span>66<span>]</span></a></sup> Some neighborhoods are named after the hill on which they are situated, including <a href=\"/wiki/Nob_Hill,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Nob Hill, San Francisco\">Nob Hill</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Potrero_Hill,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Potrero Hill, San Francisco\">Potrero Hill</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Russian_Hill,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Russian Hill, San Francisco\">Russian Hill</a>. Near the geographic center of the city, southwest of the downtown area, are a series of less densely populated hills. <a href=\"/wiki/Twin_Peaks_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Twin Peaks (San Francisco)\">Twin Peaks</a>, a pair of hills forming one of the city's highest points, forms a popular overlook spot. San Francisco's tallest hill, <a href=\"/wiki/Mount_Davidson_(California)\" title=\"Mount Davidson (California)\">Mount Davidson</a>, is 925 feet (282&#160;m) high and is capped with a 103-foot (31&#160;m) tall cross built in 1934.<sup id=\"cite_ref-67\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-67\"><span>[</span>67<span>]</span></a></sup> Dominating this area is <a href=\"/wiki/Sutro_Tower\" title=\"Sutro Tower\">Sutro Tower</a>, a large red and white radio and television transmission tower.</p>\n<p>The nearby <a href=\"/wiki/San_Andreas_Fault\" title=\"San Andreas Fault\">San Andreas</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Hayward_Fault\" title=\"Hayward Fault\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Hayward Faults</a> are responsible for much earthquake activity, although neither physically passes through the city itself. The San Andreas Fault caused the earthquakes in 1906 and 1989. Minor earthquakes occur on a regular basis. The threat of major earthquakes plays a large role in the city's infrastructure development. The city constructed an <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Fire_Department_Auxiliary_Water_Supply_System\" title=\"San Francisco Fire Department Auxiliary Water Supply System\">auxiliary water supply system</a> and has repeatedly upgraded its building codes, requiring retrofits for older buildings and higher engineering standards for new construction.<sup id=\"cite_ref-68\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-68\"><span>[</span>68<span>]</span></a></sup> However, there are still thousands of smaller buildings that remain vulnerable to quake damage.<sup id=\"cite_ref-69\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-69\"><span>[</span>69<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>San Francisco's shoreline has grown beyond its natural limits. Entire neighborhoods such as the <a href=\"/wiki/Marina_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Marina District, San Francisco\">Marina</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_Bay,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Mission Bay, San Francisco\">Mission Bay</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Hunters_Point,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Hunters Point, San Francisco\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Hunters Point</a>, as well as large sections of the <a href=\"/wiki/The_Embarcadero_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"The Embarcadero (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Embarcadero</a>, sit on areas of <a href=\"/wiki/Land_reclamation\" title=\"Land reclamation\">landfill</a>. <a href=\"/wiki/Treasure_Island,_California\" title=\"Treasure Island, California\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Treasure Island</a> was constructed from material dredged from the bay as well as material resulting from tunneling through Yerba Buena Island during the construction of the Bay Bridge. Such land tends to be unstable during earthquakes. The resulting <a href=\"/wiki/Earthquake_liquefaction\" title=\"Earthquake liquefaction\" class=\"mw-redirect\">liquefaction</a> causes extensive damage to property built upon it, as was evidenced in the Marina district during the <a href=\"/wiki/1989_Loma_Prieta_earthquake\" title=\"1989 Loma Prieta earthquake\">1989 Loma Prieta earthquake</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-70\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-70\"><span>[</span>70<span>]</span></a></sup> Most of the city's natural watercourses, such as <a href=\"/wiki/Islais_Creek\" title=\"Islais Creek\">Islais Creek</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_Creek\" title=\"Mission Creek\">Mission Creek</a>, have been culverted and built over, although the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Public_Utilities_Commission\" title=\"San Francisco Public Utilities Commission\">Public Utilities Commission</a> is studying proposals to daylight or restore some creeks.<sup id=\"cite_ref-71\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-71\"><span>[</span>71<span>]</span></a></sup></p>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Cityscape","number":"2.1","index":"3","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Cityscape","id":3,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_Landmarks_and_Historic_Places_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of Landmarks and Historic Places in San Francisco\">List of Landmarks and Historic Places in San Francisco</a></div>\n<div class=\"thumb tnone\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; width:99%; max-width:1688px;\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\">\n<div class=\"overflowbugx\" style=\"overflow:auto;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SanFrancisco_from_TwinPeaks_dusk_MC.jpg\" class=\"image\" title=\"Downtown San Francisco, seen from Twin Peaks 5:52 pm, 27 October 2006.\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/SanFrancisco_from_TwinPeaks_dusk_MC.jpg/1680px-SanFrancisco_from_TwinPeaks_dusk_MC.jpg\" width=\"1680\" height=\"322\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/SanFrancisco_from_TwinPeaks_dusk_MC.jpg/2520px-SanFrancisco_from_TwinPeaks_dusk_MC.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/c/cd/SanFrancisco_from_TwinPeaks_dusk_MC.jpg/3360px-SanFrancisco_from_TwinPeaks_dusk_MC.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"8000\" data-file-height=\"1531\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SanFrancisco_from_TwinPeaks_dusk_MC.jpg\" title=\"File:SanFrancisco from TwinPeaks dusk MC.jpg\"></a></div>\n<center>Downtown San Francisco, seen from <a href=\"/wiki/Twin_Peaks_(San_Francisco,_California)\" title=\"Twin Peaks (San Francisco, California)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Twin Peaks</a> 5:52 pm, 27 October 2006.</center>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"thumb tnone\" style=\"margin-left: auto; margin-right:auto; width:99%; max-width:1208px;\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\">\n<div class=\"overflowbugx\" style=\"overflow:auto;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:San_Francisco_(Evening).jpg\" class=\"image\" title=\"Downtown San Francisco, seen from Twin Peaks at night in June 2011.\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/San_Francisco_%28Evening%29.jpg/1200px-San_Francisco_%28Evening%29.jpg\" width=\"1200\" height=\"370\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/San_Francisco_%28Evening%29.jpg/1800px-San_Francisco_%28Evening%29.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3b/San_Francisco_%28Evening%29.jpg/2400px-San_Francisco_%28Evening%29.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"5184\" data-file-height=\"1600\" /></a></div>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:San_Francisco_(Evening).jpg\" title=\"File:San Francisco (Evening).jpg\"></a></div>\n<center>Downtown San Francisco, seen from <a href=\"/wiki/Twin_Peaks_(San_Francisco,_California)\" title=\"Twin Peaks (San Francisco, California)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Twin Peaks</a> at night in June 2011.</center>\n</div>\n</div>\n</div>"},{"toclevel":3,"level":"4","line":"Neighborhoods","number":"2.1.1","index":"4","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Neighborhoods","id":4,"text":"<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:172px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SF_Chinatown_CA.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/SF_Chinatown_CA.jpg/170px-SF_Chinatown_CA.jpg\" width=\"170\" height=\"227\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/SF_Chinatown_CA.jpg/255px-SF_Chinatown_CA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/29/SF_Chinatown_CA.jpg/340px-SF_Chinatown_CA.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"1704\" data-file-height=\"2272\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SF_Chinatown_CA.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nSan Francisco's <a href=\"/wiki/Chinatown,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Chinatown, San Francisco\">Chinatown</a> is the oldest and one of the largest in North America.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a href=\"/wiki/Neighborhoods_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"Neighborhoods in San Francisco\">Neighborhoods in San Francisco</a></div>\n<div class=\"hatnote boilerplate seealso\">See also: <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_tallest_buildings_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of tallest buildings in San Francisco\">List of tallest buildings in San Francisco</a></div>\n<p>The historic center of San Francisco is the northeast quadrant of the city anchored by <a href=\"/wiki/Market_Street_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Market Street (San Francisco)\">Market Street</a> and the waterfront. It is here that the <a href=\"/wiki/Financial_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Financial District, San Francisco\">Financial District</a> is centered, with <a href=\"/wiki/Union_Square_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Union Square (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Union Square</a>, the principal shopping and hotel district, nearby. <a href=\"/wiki/Cable_car_(railway)\" title=\"Cable car (railway)\">Cable cars</a> carry riders up steep inclines to the summit of <a href=\"/wiki/Nob_Hill\" title=\"Nob Hill\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Nob Hill</a>, once the home of the city's business tycoons, and down to the waterfront tourist attractions of <a href=\"/wiki/Fisherman%27s_Wharf,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco\">Fisherman's Wharf</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Pier_39\" title=\"Pier 39\">Pier 39</a>, where many restaurants feature <a href=\"/wiki/Dungeness_crab\" title=\"Dungeness crab\">Dungeness crab</a> from a still-active fishing industry. Also in this quadrant are <a href=\"/wiki/Russian_Hill,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Russian Hill, San Francisco\">Russian Hill</a>, a residential neighborhood with the famously crooked <a href=\"/wiki/Lombard_Street_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Lombard Street (San Francisco)\">Lombard Street</a>; <a href=\"/wiki/North_Beach,_San_Francisco\" title=\"North Beach, San Francisco\">North Beach</a>, the city's <a href=\"/wiki/Little_Italy\" title=\"Little Italy\">Little Italy</a> and the former center of the <a href=\"/wiki/Beat_Generation\" title=\"Beat Generation\">Beat Generation</a>; and <a href=\"/wiki/Telegraph_Hill,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Telegraph Hill, San Francisco\">Telegraph Hill</a>, which features <a href=\"/wiki/Coit_Tower\" title=\"Coit Tower\">Coit Tower</a>. Between Russian Hill and North Beach is San Francisco's <a href=\"/wiki/Chinatown,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Chinatown, San Francisco\">Chinatown</a>, the oldest <a href=\"/wiki/Chinatown\" title=\"Chinatown\">Chinatown</a> in North America.<sup id=\"cite_ref-72\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-72\"><span>[</span>72<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-73\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-73\"><span>[</span>73<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-Bacon.2C_Daniel_pages_52-53_74-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Bacon.2C_Daniel_pages_52-53-74\"><span>[</span>74<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-75\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-75\"><span>[</span>75<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/South_of_Market,_San_Francisco\" title=\"South of Market, San Francisco\">South of Market</a>, which was once San Francisco's industrial core, has seen significant redevelopment following the addition of <a href=\"/wiki/AT%26T_Park\" title=\"AT&amp;T Park\">AT&amp;T Park</a> and an infusion of <a href=\"/wiki/Startup_company\" title=\"Startup company\">startup companies</a>. New skyscrapers, live-work lofts, and condominiums dot the area. Further development is taking place just to the south in <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_Bay,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Mission Bay, San Francisco\">Mission Bay</a>, a former railyard now anchored by a second campus of the <a href=\"/wiki/University_of_California,_San_Francisco\" title=\"University of California, San Francisco\">University of California, San Francisco</a>.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:DowntownSF.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/75/DowntownSF.jpg/220px-DowntownSF.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"165\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/75/DowntownSF.jpg/330px-DowntownSF.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/en/thumb/7/75/DowntownSF.jpg/440px-DowntownSF.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"1600\" data-file-height=\"1200\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:DowntownSF.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\n<a href=\"/wiki/Financial_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Financial District, San Francisco\">Financial District</a> from the Bay Bridge</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>West of downtown, across <a href=\"/wiki/Van_Ness_Avenue_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Van Ness Avenue (San Francisco)\">Van Ness Avenue</a>, lies the large <a href=\"/wiki/Western_Addition,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Western Addition, San Francisco\">Western Addition</a> neighborhood, which became established with a large African American population after <a href=\"/wiki/World_War_II\" title=\"World War II\">World War II</a>. The Western Addition is usually divided into smaller neighborhoods including <a href=\"/wiki/Hayes_Valley,_San_Francisco,_California\" title=\"Hayes Valley, San Francisco, California\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Hayes Valley</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Fillmore_District,_San_Francisco,_California\" title=\"Fillmore District, San Francisco, California\" class=\"mw-redirect\">the Fillmore</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Japantown,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Japantown, San Francisco\">Japantown</a>, which was once the largest Japantown in North America but suffered when its <a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_American\" title=\"Japanese American\">Japanese American</a> residents were <a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_American_internment\" title=\"Japanese American internment\" class=\"mw-redirect\">forcibly removed and interned</a> during World War II. The Western Addition survived the <a href=\"/wiki/1906_San_Francisco_earthquake\" title=\"1906 San Francisco earthquake\">1906 earthquake</a> with its <a href=\"/wiki/Victorian_house\" title=\"Victorian house\">Victorians</a> largely intact, including the famous \"<a href=\"/wiki/Painted_Ladies\" title=\"Painted Ladies\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Painted Ladies</a>\", standing alongside <a href=\"/wiki/Alamo_Square\" title=\"Alamo Square\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Alamo Square</a>. To the south, near the geographic center of the city is <a href=\"/wiki/Haight-Ashbury\" title=\"Haight-Ashbury\">Haight-Ashbury</a>, famously associated with 1960s <a href=\"/wiki/Hippie\" title=\"Hippie\">hippie</a> culture. The Haight is now home to some expensive boutiques<sup id=\"cite_ref-76\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-76\"><span>[</span>76<span>]</span></a></sup> and a few controversial chain stores,<sup id=\"cite_ref-77\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-77\"><span>[</span>77<span>]</span></a></sup> although it still retains some <a href=\"/wiki/Bohemianism\" title=\"Bohemianism\">bohemian</a> character. North of the Western Addition is <a href=\"/wiki/Pacific_Heights,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Pacific Heights, San Francisco\">Pacific Heights</a>, a wealthy neighborhood that features the mansions built by the San Francisco business elite in the wake of the 1906 earthquake. Directly north of Pacific Heights facing the waterfront is the <a href=\"/wiki/Marina_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Marina District, San Francisco\">Marina</a>, a neighborhood popular with young professionals that was largely built on reclaimed land from the Bay.<sup id=\"cite_ref-78\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-78\"><span>[</span>78<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:172px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SF_Transamerica_full_CA.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/SF_Transamerica_full_CA.jpg/170px-SF_Transamerica_full_CA.jpg\" width=\"170\" height=\"296\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/SF_Transamerica_full_CA.jpg/255px-SF_Transamerica_full_CA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/8a/SF_Transamerica_full_CA.jpg/340px-SF_Transamerica_full_CA.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"3000\" data-file-height=\"5221\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SF_Transamerica_full_CA.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe <a href=\"/wiki/Transamerica_Pyramid\" title=\"Transamerica Pyramid\">Transamerica Pyramid</a> is the tallest building in San Francisco</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>In the south-east quadrant of the city is the <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_District\" title=\"Mission District\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Mission District</a>\u2014populated in the 19th century by <a href=\"/wiki/Californio\" title=\"Californio\">Californios</a> and working-class immigrants from Germany, Ireland, Italy, and Scandinavia. In the 1910s, a wave of Central American immigrants settled in the Mission and, in the 1950s, immigrants from <a href=\"/wiki/Mexican_American\" title=\"Mexican American\">Mexico</a> began to predominate.<sup id=\"cite_ref-79\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-79\"><span>[</span>79<span>]</span></a></sup> In recent years, gentrification has changed the demographics of parts of the Mission from Latino, to <a href=\"/wiki/Twentysomething_(term)\" title=\"Twentysomething (term)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">twenty-something</a> professionals. <a href=\"/wiki/Noe_Valley,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Noe Valley, San Francisco\">Noe Valley</a> to the southwest and <a href=\"/wiki/Bernal_Heights,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Bernal Heights, San Francisco\">Bernal Heights</a> to the south are both increasingly popular among young families with children. East of the Mission is the <a href=\"/wiki/Potrero_Hill\" title=\"Potrero Hill\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Potrero Hill</a> neighborhood, a mostly residential neighborhood that features sweeping views of downtown San Francisco. West of the Mission, the area historically known as <a href=\"/wiki/Eureka_Valley_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Eureka Valley (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Eureka Valley</a>, now popularly called <a href=\"/wiki/The_Castro,_San_Francisco\" title=\"The Castro, San Francisco\">the Castro</a>, was once a working-class Scandinavian and Irish area. It has become North America's first and best known <a href=\"/wiki/Gay_village\" title=\"Gay village\">gay village</a>, and is now the center of <a href=\"/wiki/Homosexuality\" title=\"Homosexuality\">gay</a> life in the city.<sup id=\"cite_ref-80\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-80\"><span>[</span>80<span>]</span></a></sup> Located near the city's southern border, the <a href=\"/wiki/Excelsior_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Excelsior District, San Francisco\">Excelsior District</a> is one of the most ethnically diverse neighborhoods in San Francisco. The predominately African American <a href=\"/wiki/Hunters_Point,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Hunters Point, San Francisco\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Bayview-Hunters Point</a> in the far southeast corner of the city is one of the poorest neighborhoods and suffers from a high rate of crime, though the area has been the focus of several revitalizing and controversial <a href=\"/wiki/Urban_renewal\" title=\"Urban renewal\">urban renewal</a> projects.</p>\n<p>The construction of the <a href=\"/wiki/Twin_Peaks_Tunnel\" title=\"Twin Peaks Tunnel\">Twin Peaks Tunnel</a> in 1918 connected southwest neighborhoods to downtown via streetcar, hastening the development of <a href=\"/wiki/West_Portal,_San_Francisco\" title=\"West Portal, San Francisco\">West Portal</a>, and nearby affluent <a href=\"/wiki/Forest_Hill,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Forest Hill, San Francisco\">Forest Hill</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/St._Francis_Wood,_San_Francisco\" title=\"St. Francis Wood, San Francisco\">St. Francis Wood</a>. Further west, stretching all the way to the Pacific Ocean and north to <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_Park\" title=\"Golden Gate Park\">Golden Gate Park</a> lies the vast <a href=\"/wiki/Sunset_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Sunset District, San Francisco\">Sunset District</a>, a large middle class area with a predominantly Asian population.<sup id=\"cite_ref-81\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-81\"><span>[</span>81<span>]</span></a></sup> The northwestern quadrant of the city contains the <a href=\"/wiki/Richmond_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Richmond District, San Francisco\">Richmond</a>, also a mostly middle-class neighborhood north of Golden Gate Park, home to immigrants from other parts of Asia as well as many <a href=\"/wiki/Russian_people\" title=\"Russian people\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Russian</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Ukrainian_people\" title=\"Ukrainian people\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Ukrainian</a> immigrants. Together, these areas are known as <a href=\"/wiki/Neighborhoods_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"Neighborhoods in San Francisco\">The Avenues</a>. These two districts are each sometimes further divided into two regions: the Outer Richmond and Outer Sunset can refer to the more western portions of their respective district and the Inner Richmond and Inner Sunset can refer to the more eastern portions.</p>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Climate","number":"2.2","index":"5","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Climate","id":5,"text":"<table class=\"infobox\" style=\"width: 19.5em; style=\"color:red;position:absolute;bottom:8.8066666666667em; left:0;width:1.5em;height:1.5em;text-align:center;\"><span style=\"font-size:80%\">53</span></div>\n</div>\n</td>\n<td>\n<div style=\"width:1.5em;height:17em;position:relative;padding:0;margin:0\">\n<div style=\"height:6em;bottom:2em;width:1.5em;position:absolute;left:0;border-top:dotted 1px #cba;border-bottom:dotted 1px style=\"color:blue;position:absolute;bottom:.5em;left:0;width:1.5em;height:1.5em;text-align:center\"><span style=\"font-size:70%\">0</span></div>\n<div style=\"overflow:hidden;background:#e44;position:absolute;left:.4em;width:0.8em;bottom:10.451111111111em;height:1.3777777777778em;\">&#160;</div>\n<div style=\"color:red;position:absolute;bottom:11.828888888889em; left:0;width:1.5em;height:1.5em;text-align:center;\"><span style=\"font-size:80%\">67</span></div>\n<div style=\"color:red;position:absolute;bottom:8.9511111111111em; left:0;width:1.5em;height:1.5em;text-align:center;\"><span style=\"font-size:80%\">54</span></div>\n</div>\n</td>\n<td>\n<div style=\"width:1.5em;height:17em;position:relative;padding:0;margin:0\">\n<div style=\"height:6em;bottom:2em;width:1.5em;position:absolute;left:0;border-top:dotted 1px #cba;border-bottom:dotted 1px #abc;padding:0;margin:0\">&#160;</div>\n<div style=\"background:#ace;position:absolute;bottom:2em;left:.2em;width:1.2em;height:0.03048em;overflow:hidden\">&#160;</div>\n<div colspan=\"12\" style=\"padding: 2px; text-align: left; line-height: 1.5em; color: red\">Average max. and min. temperatures in \u00b0C</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<td colspan=\"12\" style=\"padding: 2px; text-align: left; line-height: 1.5em; color: blue\">Precipitation totals in mm</td>\n</tr>\n</table>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</table>\n<p>A popular quote incorrectly attributed to <a href=\"/wiki/Mark_Twain\" title=\"Mark Twain\">Mark Twain</a> is \"The coldest winter I ever spent was a summer in San Francisco.\"<sup id=\"cite_ref-marktwain_83-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-marktwain-83\"><span>[</span>83<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-84\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-84\"><span>[</span>84<span>]</span></a></sup> San Francisco's climate is characteristic of the cool-summer <a href=\"/wiki/Mediterranean_climate\" title=\"Mediterranean climate\">Mediterranean climate</a> (<a href=\"/wiki/Warm-summer_Mediterranean_climate\" title=\"Warm-summer Mediterranean climate\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Csb</a>)<sup id=\"cite_ref-85\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-85\"><span>[</span>85<span>]</span></a></sup> of California\u2019s coast, \"generally characterized by moist mild winters and dry summers\".<sup id=\"cite_ref-86\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-86\"><span>[</span>86<span>]</span></a></sup> Since it is surrounded on three sides by water, San Francisco's weather is strongly influenced by the <a href=\"/wiki/California_Current\" title=\"California Current\">cool currents</a> of the Pacific Ocean, which moderate temperature swings and produce a remarkably mild year-round climate with little seasonal temperature variation.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:172px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:San_francisco_in_fog_with_rays.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/San_francisco_in_fog_with_rays.jpg/170px-San_francisco_in_fog_with_rays.jpg\" width=\"170\" height=\"183\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/San_francisco_in_fog_with_rays.jpg/255px-San_francisco_in_fog_with_rays.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/San_francisco_in_fog_with_rays.jpg/340px-San_francisco_in_fog_with_rays.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"3000\" data-file-height=\"3222\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:San_francisco_in_fog_with_rays.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\n<a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_fog\" title=\"San Francisco fog\">Fog</a> is a regular feature of San Francisco summers.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Among major U.S. cities, San Francisco has the coldest daily mean, maximum, and minimum temperatures for June, July, and August.<sup id=\"cite_ref-87\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-87\"><span>[</span>87<span>]</span></a></sup> During the summer, rising hot air in California's interior valleys creates a low pressure area that draws winds from the <a href=\"/wiki/North_Pacific_High\" title=\"North Pacific High\">North Pacific High</a> through the Golden Gate, which creates the city's <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_fog_generation\" title=\"San Francisco fog generation\" class=\"mw-redirect\">characteristic cool winds and fog</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-88\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-88\"><span>[</span>88<span>]</span></a></sup> The fog is less pronounced in eastern neighborhoods and during the late summer and early fall, which is the warmest time of the year.</p>\n<p>Because of its sharp topography and maritime influences, San Francisco exhibits a multitude of distinct <a href=\"/wiki/Microclimate\" title=\"Microclimate\">microclimates</a>. The high hills in the geographic center of the city are responsible for a 20% variance in annual rainfall between different parts of the city. They also protect neighborhoods directly to their east (\"banana belts\" such as Noe Valley) from the foggy and sometimes very cold and windy conditions experienced in the <a href=\"/wiki/Sunset_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Sunset District, San Francisco\">Sunset District</a>; for those who live on the eastern side of the city, San Francisco is sunnier, with an average of 260 clear days, and only 105 cloudy days per year.</p>\n<p>Temperatures reach or exceed 80&#160;\u00b0F (27&#160;\u00b0C) on an average of only 21 and 23&#160;days a year at downtown and SFO, respectively.<sup id=\"cite_ref-NOAA_82-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-NOAA-82\"><span>[</span>82<span>]</span></a></sup> The dry period of May to October is mild to warm, with the normal monthly mean temperature peaking in September at 62.7&#160;\u00b0F (17.1&#160;\u00b0C).<sup id=\"cite_ref-NOAA_82-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-NOAA-82\"><span>[</span>82<span>]</span></a></sup> The rainy period of November to April is slightly cooler, with the normal monthly mean temperature reaching its lowest in January at 51.3&#160;\u00b0F (10.7&#160;\u00b0C).<sup id=\"cite_ref-NOAA_82-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-NOAA-82\"><span>[</span>82<span>]</span></a></sup> On average, there are 73 rainy days a year, and annual precipitation averages 23.65 inches (601&#160;mm).<sup id=\"cite_ref-NOAA_82-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-NOAA-82\"><span>[</span>82<span>]</span></a></sup> Variation in precipitation from year to year is high. In 2013, a record low 5.59&#160;in (142&#160;mm) of rainfall was recorded at downtown San Francisco, where records have been kept since 1849;<sup id=\"cite_ref-NOAA_82-5\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-NOAA-82\"><span>[</span>82<span>]</span></a></sup> low records were shattered in much of the state. Snowfall in the city is very rare, with only 10 measurable accumulations recorded since 1852, most recently in 1976 when up to 5 inches (130&#160;mm) fell on Twin Peaks.<sup id=\"cite_ref-89\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-89\"><span>[</span>89<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-90\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-90\"><span>[</span>90<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>The highest recorded temperature at the official <a href=\"/wiki/National_Weather_Service\" title=\"National Weather Service\">National Weather Service</a> office was 103&#160;\u00b0F (39&#160;\u00b0C) on July 17, 1988, and June 14, 2000. The lowest recorded temperature was 27&#160;\u00b0F (\u22123&#160;\u00b0C) on December 11, 1932.<sup id=\"cite_ref-91\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-91\"><span>[</span>91<span>]</span></a></sup> The National Weather Service provides a helpful visual aid<sup id=\"cite_ref-92\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-92\"><span>[</span>92<span>]</span></a></sup> graphing the information in the table below to display visually by month the annual typical temperatures, the past year's temperatures, and record temperatures.</p>\n<p>San Francisco falls under the <a href=\"/wiki/USDA\" title=\"USDA\" class=\"mw-redirect\">USDA</a> 10b Plant <a href=\"/wiki/Hardiness_zone\" title=\"Hardiness zone\">Hardiness zone</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-93\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-93\"><span>[</span>93<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p><br /></p>\n<table class=\"wikitable collapsible collapsed\" style=\"width:90%; text-align:center; font-size:90%; line-height: 1.1em; margin:auto;\">\n<tr>\n<th colspan=\"14\">Climate data for San Francisco (downtown),<sup id=\"cite_ref-94\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-2013CensusEst-16\"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-1849pop_32-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-1849pop-32\"><span>[</span>32<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-SFCensus2010_99-0\" class=\"reference\"><a
