title=\"File:SFPopulation.svg\">Population Graph</a></div>\n</td>\n</tr>\n</table>\n<p>The <a href=\"/wiki/2010_United_States_Census\" title=\"2010 United States Census\">2010 United States Census</a><sup id=\"cite_ref-101\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-101\"><span>[</span>100<span>]</span></a></sup> reported that San Francisco had a population of 805,235. With a <a href=\"/wiki/Population_density\" title=\"Population density\">population density</a> of 17,160 per square mile (6,632/km<sup>2</sup>), San Francisco is the <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_United_States_cities_by_population_density\" title=\"List of United States cities by population density\">second-most densely populated</a> major American city (among cities greater than 200,000 population).<sup id=\"cite_ref-SF_Population_Density_19-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SF_Population_Density-19\"><span>[</span>19<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>San Francisco is the traditional focal point of the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay_Area\" title=\"San Francisco Bay Area\">San Francisco Bay Area</a> and forms part of the five-county <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco%E2%80%93Oakland%E2%80%93Fremont,_CA_Metropolitan_Statistical_Area\" title=\"San Francisco\u2013Oakland\u2013Fremont, CA Metropolitan Statistical Area\" class=\"mw-redirect\">San Francisco\u2013Oakland\u2013Fremont, CA Metropolitan Statistical Area</a>, a region of 4.5 million people. It is also classified as part of the greater 12-county <a href=\"/wiki/San_Jose-San_Francisco-Oakland,_CA_Combined_Statistical_Area\" title=\"San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland, CA Combined Statistical Area\">San Jose-San Francisco-Oakland, CA Combined Statistical Area</a>, whose population is over 8.4 million, making it the fifth-largest in the United States as of 2013.<sup id=\"cite_ref-102\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-102\"><span>[</span>101<span>]</span></a></sup> The U.S. Census Bureau estimates San Francisco's population increased to 837,442 as of July 2013.<sup id=\"cite_ref-2013CensusEst_16-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-2013CensusEst-16\"><span>[</span>16<span>]</span></a></sup></p>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Race and ethnicity","number":"3.1","index":"7","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Race_and_ethnicity","id":7,"text":"<p>As of the 2010 census, the ethnic makeup and population of San Francisco included: 390,387 <a href=\"/wiki/White_(U.S._Census)\" title=\"White (U.S. Census)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Whites</a> (48.1%), 267,915 <a href=\"/wiki/Asian_(U.S._Census)\" title=\"Asian (U.S. Census)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Asians</a> (33.3%), 48,870 <a href=\"/wiki/African_American_(U.S._Census)\" title=\"African American (U.S. Census)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">African Americans</a> (6.1%), 4,024 <a href=\"/wiki/Native_American_(U.S._Census)\" title=\"Native American (U.S. Census)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Native Americans</a> (0.5%), 3,359 <a href=\"/wiki/Pacific_Islander_(U.S._Census)\" title=\"Pacific Islander (U.S. Census)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Pacific Islanders</a> (0.4%), 53,021 from <a href=\"/wiki/Race_(United_States_Census)\" title=\"Race (United States Census)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">other races</a> (6.6%), and 37,659 from two or more races (4.7%). There were 121,744 <a href=\"/wiki/Hispanic_(U.S._Census)\" title=\"Hispanic (U.S. Census)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Hispanics</a> or <a href=\"/wiki/Latino_(U.S._Census)\" title=\"Latino (U.S. Census)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Latinos</a> of any race (15.1%).</p>\n<p>San Francisco has a <a href=\"/wiki/Minority-majority\" title=\"Minority-majority\" class=\"mw-redirect\">minority-majority</a> population, as non-Hispanic <a href=\"/wiki/White_American\" title=\"White American\">whites</a> comprise less than half of the population, 41.9%, down from 92.5% in 1940.<sup id=\"cite_ref-census_37-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-census-37\"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> The principal <a href=\"/wiki/Hispanics_in_the_United_States\" title=\"Hispanics in the United States\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Hispanic</a> groups in the city were those of <a href=\"/wiki/Mexican_American\" title=\"Mexican American\">Mexican</a> (7.4%), <a href=\"/wiki/Salvadoran_American\" title=\"Salvadoran American\">Salvadoran</a> (2.0%), <a href=\"/wiki/Nicaraguan_American\" title=\"Nicaraguan American\">Nicaraguan</a> (0.9%), <a href=\"/wiki/Guatemalan_American\" title=\"Guatemalan American\">Guatemalan</a> (0.8%), and <a href=\"/wiki/Stateside_Puerto_Rican\" title=\"Stateside Puerto Rican\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Puerto Rican</a> (0.5%), ancestry. The Hispanic population is most heavily concentrated in the <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Mission District, San Francisco\">Mission District</a>, Tenderloin District, and <a href=\"/wiki/Excelsior_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Excelsior District, San Francisco\">Excelsior District</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-interactivemap_103-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-interactivemap-103\"><span>[</span>102<span>]</span></a></sup> San Francisco's <a href=\"/wiki/Black_American\" title=\"Black American\" class=\"mw-redirect\">African American</a> population has declined in recent decades,<sup id=\"cite_ref-census_37-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-census-37\"><span>[</span>37<span>]</span></a></sup> from 13.4% of the population in 1970 to 6.1%.<sup id=\"cite_ref-SF_QuickFacts_104-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SF_QuickFacts-104\"><span>[</span>103<span>]</span></a></sup> The current percentage of African Americans in San Francisco is similar to that of the state of California;<sup id=\"cite_ref-SF_QuickFacts_104-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SF_QuickFacts-104\"><span>[</span>103<span>]</span></a></sup> conversely, the city's percentage of Hispanic residents is less than half of that of the state. The majority of the city's black population reside within the neighborhoods of <a href=\"/wiki/Bayview-Hunters_Point,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Bayview-Hunters Point, San Francisco\">Bayview-Hunters Point</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Visitacion_Valley,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Visitacion Valley, San Francisco\">Visitacion Valley</a> in southeastern San Francisco, and in the <a href=\"/wiki/Fillmore_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Fillmore District, San Francisco\">Fillmore District</a> in the northeastern part of the city.<sup id=\"cite_ref-interactivemap_103-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-interactivemap-103\"><span>[</span>102<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>In 2010, residents of <a href=\"/wiki/Chinese_American\" title=\"Chinese American\">Chinese ethnicity</a> constituted the largest single ethnic minority group in San Francisco at 21.4% of the population; the other Asian groups are <a href=\"/wiki/Filipino_American\" title=\"Filipino American\">Filipinos</a> (4.5%), <a href=\"/wiki/Vietnamese_American\" title=\"Vietnamese American\">Vietnamese</a> (1.6%), <a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_American\" title=\"Japanese American\">Japanese</a> (1.3%), <a href=\"/wiki/Indian_American\" title=\"Indian American\">Asian Indians</a> (1.2%), <a href=\"/wiki/Korean_American\" title=\"Korean American\">Koreans</a> (1.2%), <a href=\"/wiki/Thai_American\" title=\"Thai American\">Thais</a> (0.3%), <a href=\"/wiki/Burmese_American\" title=\"Burmese American\">Burmese</a> (0.2%), <a href=\"/wiki/Cambodian_American\" title=\"Cambodian American\">Cambodians</a> (0.2%), and <a href=\"/wiki/Indonesian_American\" title=\"Indonesian American\">Indonesians</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Laotian_American\" title=\"Laotian American\">Laotians</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Mongolian_American\" title=\"Mongolian American\">Mongolians</a> make up less than 0.1% of the city's population.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Census_2010-GCT-PH1_14-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Census_2010-GCT-PH1-14\"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup> The population of Chinese ancestry is most heavily concentrated in Chinatown, <a href=\"/wiki/Sunset_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Sunset District, San Francisco\">Sunset District</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Richmond_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Richmond District, San Francisco\">Richmond District</a>, whereas Filipinos are most concentrated in the <a href=\"/wiki/Crocker-Amazon,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Crocker-Amazon, San Francisco\">Crocker-Amazon</a> (which is continuous with the Filipino community of <a href=\"/wiki/Daly_City,_California\" title=\"Daly City, California\">Daly City</a>, the city with one of the highest concentrations of Filipinos in North America), as well as in <a href=\"/wiki/South_of_Market,_San_Francisco\" title=\"South of Market, San Francisco\">SoMa</a>.</p>\n<p>After declining in the 1970s and 1980s, the <a href=\"/wiki/Filipino_American\" title=\"Filipino American\">Filipino</a> community in the city has experienced a significant resurgence. The San Francisco Bay Area is home to over 382,950 Filipino Americans, one of the largest communities of Filipinos outside of the Philippines.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Census_2010-GCT-PH1_14-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Census_2010-GCT-PH1-14\"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-105\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-105\"><span>[</span>104<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/Tenderloin,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Tenderloin, San Francisco\">Tenderloin District</a> is home to a large portion of the city's Vietnamese population as well as businesses and restaurants, which is known as the city's Little Saigon. Koreans and Japanese have a large presence in the <a href=\"/wiki/Western_Addition,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Western Addition, San Francisco\">Western Addition</a>, which is where the city's <a href=\"/wiki/Japantown,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Japantown, San Francisco\">Japantown</a> is located. The <a href=\"/wiki/Pacific_Islander_American\" title=\"Pacific Islander American\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Pacific Islander</a> population is 0.4% (0.8% including those with partial ancestry). Over half of the Pacific Islander population is of <a href=\"/wiki/Samoan_American\" title=\"Samoan American\">Samoan</a> descent, with residence in the <a href=\"/wiki/Bayview-Hunters_Point,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Bayview-Hunters Point, San Francisco\">Bayview-Hunters Point</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Visitacion_Valley,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Visitacion Valley, San Francisco\">Visitacion Valley</a> areas; Pacific Islanders make up more than three percent of the population in both communities.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Census_2010-GCT-PH1_14-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Census_2010-GCT-PH1-14\"><span>[</span>14<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>Native-born Californians form a relatively small percentage of the city's population: only 37.7% of its residents were born in California, while 25.2% were born in a different U.S. state. More than a third of city residents (35.6%) were born outside the United States.<sup id=\"cite_ref-SF_QuickFacts_104-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SF_QuickFacts-104\"><span>[</span>103<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<table>\n<tr>\n<td align=\"left\">\n<table class=\"wikitable sortable collapsible\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Non-Hispanic White</a></td>\n<td>41.9%</td>\n<td>43.6%</td>\n<td>46.6%</td>\n<td>60.4%<sup id=\"cite_ref-fifteen_109-1\" class=\"reference\"><a households, and income","number":"3.2","index":"8","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Education.2C_households.2C_and_income","id":8,"text":"<p>Of all major cities, San Francisco has the second-highest percentage of residents with a college degree, behind only <a href=\"/wiki/Seattle\" title=\"Seattle\">Seattle</a>. Over 44% of adults within the city limits have a bachelor's or higher degree.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Bizjournals_110-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Bizjournals-110\"><span>[</span>109<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href=\"/wiki/USA_Today\" title=\"USA Today\">USA Today</a></i> reported that Rob Pitingolo, a researcher who measured college graduates per square mile, found that San Francisco had the highest rate at 7,031 per square mile, or over 344,000 total graduates in the city's 46.7 square miles (121&#160;km<sup>2</sup>).<sup id=\"cite_ref-USA_Today_111-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-USA_Today-111\"><span>[</span>110<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>The Census reported that 780,971 people (97.0% of the population) lived in households, 18,902 (2.3%) lived in non-institutionalized group quarters, and 5,362 (0.7%) were institutionalized. There were 345,811 households, out of which 63,577 (18.4%) had children under the age of 18 living in them, 109,437 (31.6%) were <a href=\"/wiki/Marriage\" title=\"Marriage\">opposite-sex married couples</a> living together, 28,844 (8.3%) had a female householder with no spouse present, 12,748 (3.7%) had a male householder with no spouse present. There were 21,677 (6.3%) <a href=\"/wiki/POSSLQ\" title=\"POSSLQ\">unmarried opposite-sex partnerships</a>, and 10,384 (3.0%) <a href=\"/wiki/Same-sex_partnerships\" title=\"Same-sex partnerships\" class=\"mw-redirect\">same-sex married couples or partnerships</a>. 133,366 households (38.6%) were made up of individuals and 34,234 (9.9%) had someone living alone who was 65 years of age or older. The average household size was 2.26. There were 151,029 <a href=\"/wiki/Family_(U.S._Census)\" title=\"Family (U.S. Census)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">families</a> (43.7% of all households); the average family size was 3.11. There were 376,942 housing units, at an average density of 1,625.5 per square mile (627.6/km<sup>2</sup>), of which 123,646 (35.8%) were owner-occupied, and 222,165 (64.2%) were occupied by renters. The homeowner vacancy rate was 2.3%; the rental vacancy rate was 5.4%. 327,985 people (40.7% of the population) lived in owner-occupied housing units and 452,986 people (56.3%) lived in rental housing units.</p>\n<p>According to the 2005 American Community Survey, San Francisco has the highest percentage of gay and lesbian individuals of any of the 50 largest U.S. cities, at 15.4%.<sup id=\"cite_ref-112\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-112\"><span>[</span>111<span>]</span></a></sup> San Francisco also has the highest percentage of same-sex households of any American county, with the Bay Area having a higher concentration than any other <a href=\"/wiki/Metropolitan_area\" title=\"Metropolitan area\">metropolitan area</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-gaystats_113-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-gaystats-113\"><span>[</span>112<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<table class=\"wikitable\" style=\"float: right; clear: both;\">\n<tr>\n<th colspan=\"6\">Income in 2011</th>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">Per capita income<sup id=\"cite_ref-US-CB-B19301_114-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-US-CB-B19301-114\"><span>[</span>113<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td colspan=\"2\">$46,777</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">Median household income<sup id=\"cite_ref-US-CB-B19013_115-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-US-CB-B19013-115\"><span>[</span>114<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td colspan=\"2\">$72,947</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">Median family income<sup id=\"cite_ref-US-CB-B19113_116-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-US-CB-B19113-116\"><span>[</span>115<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td colspan=\"2\">$87,329</td>\n</tr>\n</table>\n<p>San Francisco ranks third of American cities in median household income<sup id=\"cite_ref-Census_ACS_2003_117-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Census_ACS_2003-117\"><span>[</span>116<span>]</span></a></sup> with a 2007 value of $65,519.<sup id=\"cite_ref-SF_QuickFacts_104-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SF_QuickFacts-104\"><span>[</span>103<span>]</span></a></sup> Median family income is $81,136,<sup id=\"cite_ref-SF_QuickFacts_104-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SF_QuickFacts-104\"><span>[</span>103<span>]</span></a></sup> and San Francisco ranks 8th of major cities worldwide in the number of billionaires known to be living within city limits.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Billionaires_in_San_Francisco_118-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Billionaires_in_San_Francisco-118\"><span>[</span>117<span>]</span></a></sup> Following a national trend, an emigration of middle-class families is contributing to widening income disparity<sup id=\"cite_ref-MiddleClass_119-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-MiddleClass-119\"><span>[</span>118<span>]</span></a></sup> and has left the city with a lower proportion of children, 14.5%, than any other large American city.<sup id=\"cite_ref-ChildPopulation_120-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-ChildPopulation-120\"><span>[</span>119<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>The city's <a href=\"/wiki/Poverty_rate\" title=\"Poverty rate\" class=\"mw-redirect\">poverty rate</a> is 11.8% and the number of families in poverty stands at 7.4%, both lower than the national average.<sup id=\"cite_ref-121\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-121\"><span>[</span>120<span>]</span></a></sup> The unemployment rate stands at 5.3% as of January 2014.<sup id=\"cite_ref-122\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-122\"><span>[</span>121<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Homelessness\" title=\"Homelessness\">Homelessness</a> has been a chronic and controversial problem for San Francisco since the early 1970s when many mentally ill patients were deinstitutionalized, due to changes which began during the 1960s with the enactment of Medicare and Medicaid.<sup id=\"cite_ref-123\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-123\"><span>[</span>122<span>]</span></a></sup> The homeless population is estimated to be 13,500 with 6,500 living on the streets.<sup id=\"cite_ref-124\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-124\"><span>[</span>123<span>]</span></a></sup> The city is believed to have the highest number of homeless inhabitants per capita of any major U.S. city.<sup id=\"cite_ref-125\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-125\"><span>[</span>124<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-126\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-126\"><span>[</span>125<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Crime_rate\" title=\"Crime rate\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Rates</a> of reported violent and property crimes for 2009 (736 and 4,262 incidents per 100,000 residents, respectively)<sup id=\"cite_ref-SFCrimeStats_127-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SFCrimeStats-127\"><span>[</span>126<span>]</span></a></sup> are slightly lower than for similarly sized U.S. cities.<sup id=\"cite_ref-128\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-128\"><span>[</span>127<span>]</span></a></sup></p>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Languages and ages","number":"3.3","index":"9","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Languages_and_ages","id":9,"text":"<p>As of 2010, 54.58% (411,728) of San Francisco residents age 5 and older spoke <a href=\"/wiki/English_language\" title=\"English language\">English</a> at home as a <a href=\"/wiki/Primary_language\" title=\"Primary language\" class=\"mw-redirect\">primary language</a>, while 18.60% (140,302) spoke <a href=\"/wiki/Chinese_language\" title=\"Chinese language\">Chinese</a>, 11.68% (88,147) <a href=\"/wiki/Spanish_language\" title=\"Spanish language\">Spanish</a>, 3.42% (25,767) <a href=\"/wiki/Tagalog_language\" title=\"Tagalog language\">Tagalog</a>, 1.86% (14,017) <a href=\"/wiki/Russian_language\" title=\"Russian language\">Russian</a>, 1.45% (10,939) <a href=\"/wiki/Vietnamese_language\" title=\"Vietnamese language\">Vietnamese</a>, 1.05% (7,895) <a href=\"/wiki/French_language\" title=\"French language\">French</a>, 0.90% (6,777) <a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_language\" title=\"Japanese language\">Japanese</a>, 0.88% (6,624) <a href=\"/wiki/Korean_language\" title=\"Korean language\">Korean</a>, 0.56% (4,215) <a href=\"/wiki/German_language\" title=\"German language\">German</a>, 0.53% (3,995) <a href=\"/wiki/Italian_language\" title=\"Italian language\">Italian</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Pacific_Islands\" title=\"Pacific Islands\">Pacific Islander languages</a> were spoken as a <a href=\"/wiki/Main_language\" title=\"Main language\" class=\"mw-redirect\">main language</a> by 0.47% (3,535) of the population over the age of five. In total, 45.42% (342,693) of San Francisco's population age 5 and older spoke a <a href=\"/wiki/Mother_language\" title=\"Mother language\" class=\"mw-redirect\">mother language</a> other than English.<sup id=\"cite_ref-129\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-129\"><span>[</span>128<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>The age distribution of the city was as follows: 107,524 people (13.4%) under the age of 18, 77,664 people (9.6%) aged 18 to 24, 301,802 people (37.5%) aged 25 to 44, 208,403 people (25.9%) aged 45 to 64, and 109,842 people (13.6%) who were 65 years of age or older. The median age was 38.5 years. For every 100 females there were 102.9 males. For every 100 females age 18 and over, there were 102.8 males.</p>"},{"toclevel":1,"level":"2","line":"Economy","number":"4","index":"10","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Economy","id":10,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote boilerplate seealso\">See also: <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_companies_based_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of companies based in San Francisco\">List of companies based in San Francisco</a></div>\n<p>San Francisco has a diversified <a href=\"/wiki/Service_economy\" title=\"Service economy\">service economy</a>, with employment spread across a wide range of professional services, including <a href=\"/wiki/Financial_services\" title=\"Financial services\">financial services</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Tourism\" title=\"Tourism\">tourism</a>, and (increasingly) <a href=\"/wiki/High_tech\" title=\"High tech\">high technology</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-caedd-2012_130-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-caedd-2012-130\"><span>[</span>129<span>]</span></a></sup> In 2012, approximately 25% of workers were employed in professional business services; 16% in government services; 15% in leisure and hospitality; 11% in education and health care; and 9% in financial activities.<sup id=\"cite_ref-caedd-2012_130-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-caedd-2012-130\"><span>[</span>129<span>]</span></a></sup> In 2012, GDP in the five-county <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco%E2%80%93Oakland%E2%80%93Hayward,_CA_Metropolitan_Statistical_Area\" title=\"San Francisco\u2013Oakland\u2013Hayward, CA Metropolitan Statistical Area\">San Francisco metropolitan area</a> grew by 7.4%, to US$360.4 billion; this was the fastest growth in the United States.<sup id=\"cite_ref-131\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-131\"><span>[</span>130<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:172px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SF_California_Street_USA.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/SF_California_Street_USA.jpg/170px-SF_California_Street_USA.jpg\" width=\"170\" height=\"227\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/SF_California_Street_USA.jpg/255px-SF_California_Street_USA.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/80/SF_California_Street_USA.jpg/340px-SF_California_Street_USA.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"1704\" data-file-height=\"2272\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SF_California_Street_USA.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nCalifornia Street in the Financial District</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The legacy of the <a href=\"/wiki/California_Gold_Rush\" title=\"California Gold Rush\">California Gold Rush</a> turned San Francisco into the principal banking and finance center of the <a href=\"/wiki/West_Coast_of_the_United_States\" title=\"West Coast of the United States\">West Coast</a> in the early twentieth century.<sup id=\"cite_ref-California2011_132-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-California2011-132\"><span>[</span>131<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Montgomery_Street\" title=\"Montgomery Street\">Montgomery Street</a> in the <a href=\"/wiki/Financial_District_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Financial District (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Financial District</a> became known as the \"<a href=\"/wiki/Wall_Street_of_the_West\" title=\"Wall Street of the West\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Wall Street of the West</a>\", home to the <a href=\"/wiki/Federal_Reserve_Bank_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco\">Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco</a>, the <a href=\"/wiki/Wells_Fargo\" title=\"Wells Fargo\">Wells Fargo</a> corporate headquarters, and the site of the now-defunct <a href=\"/wiki/Pacific_Exchange\" title=\"Pacific Exchange\">Pacific Coast Stock Exchange</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-California2011_132-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-California2011-132\"><span>[</span>131<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Bank_of_America\" title=\"Bank of America\">Bank of America</a>, a pioneer in making banking services accessible to the middle class, was founded in San Francisco and in the 1960s, built the landmark modern skyscraper at <a href=\"/wiki/555_California_Street\" title=\"555 California Street\">555 California Street</a> for its corporate headquarters. Many large financial institutions, multinational banks, and venture capital firms are based in or have regional headquarters in the city. With over 30 international financial institutions,<sup id=\"cite_ref-CityData.com_133-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-CityData.com-133\"><span>[</span>132<span>]</span></a></sup> six <a href=\"/wiki/Fortune_500\" title=\"Fortune 500\">Fortune 500</a> companies,<sup id=\"cite_ref-134\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-134\"><span>[</span>133<span>]</span></a></sup> and a large support infrastructure of professional services\u2014including law, public relations, <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_architecture\" title=\"San Francisco architecture\" class=\"mw-redirect\">architecture</a> and design\u2014San Francisco is designated as an <a href=\"/wiki/Global_city\" title=\"Global city\">Alpha(-) World City</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-135\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-135\"><span>[</span>134<span>]</span></a></sup> and is ranked in <a href=\"/wiki/Global_Financial_Centres_Index\" title=\"Global Financial Centres Index\">10th place</a> among the top global financial centers.<sup id=\"cite_ref-136\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-136\"><span>[</span>135<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Alcatraz_Island_1,_SF,_CA,_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Alcatraz_Island_1%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg/220px-Alcatraz_Island_1%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"147\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Alcatraz_Island_1%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg/330px-Alcatraz_Island_1%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/48/Alcatraz_Island_1%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg/440px-Alcatraz_Island_1%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"3456\" data-file-height=\"2304\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Alcatraz_Island_1,_SF,_CA,_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\n<a href=\"/wiki/Alcatraz_Island\" title=\"Alcatraz Island\">Alcatraz</a> receives 1.5&#160;million annual visitors.<sup id=\"cite_ref-137\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-137\"><span>[</span>136<span>]</span></a></sup></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Tourism is one of the city's largest private-sector industries,<sup id=\"cite_ref-tourism-largest-private-sector_138-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-tourism-largest-private-sector-138\"><span>[</span>137<span>]</span></a></sup> accounting for more than one out of seven jobs in the city.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Waters2009_139-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Waters2009-139\"><span>[</span>138<span>]</span></a></sup> The city's <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_in_popular_culture\" title=\"San Francisco in popular culture\">frequent portrayal</a> in music, film, and popular culture has made the city and its landmarks recognizable worldwide. San Francisco attracts the fifth-highest number of foreign tourists of any city in the U.S.<sup class=\"noprint Inline-Template\" style=\"white-space:nowrap;\">[<i><a href=\"/wiki/Wikipedia:Manual_of_Style/Dates_and_numbers#Precise_language\" title=\"Wikipedia:Manual of Style/Dates and numbers\"><span title=\"Tourism numbers published annually in May\">dated info</span></a></i>]</sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-TravelandTourism_140-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-TravelandTourism-140\"><span>[</span>139<span>]</span></a></sup> and ranks 43rd out of the 100 most visited cities worldwide according to <a href=\"/wiki/Euromonitor_International\" title=\"Euromonitor International\">Euromonitor International</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-euromonitor.com_141-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-euromonitor.com-141\"><span>[</span>140<span>]</span></a></sup> More than 16.9&#160;million visitors arrived in San Francisco in 2013, injecting US$9.4&#160;billion into the economy.<sup id=\"cite_ref-142\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-142\"><span>[</span>141<span>]</span></a></sup> With a large hotel infrastructure and a world-class convention facility in the <a href=\"/wiki/Moscone_Center\" title=\"Moscone Center\">Moscone Center</a>, San Francisco is a popular destination for annual conventions and conferences.<sup id=\"cite_ref-143\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-143\"><span>[</span>142<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>Since the 1990s, San Francisco's economy has diversified away from finance and tourism towards the growing fields of high tech, <a href=\"/wiki/Biotechnology\" title=\"Biotechnology\">biotechnology</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Medical_research\" title=\"Medical research\">medical research</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Waters2009_139-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Waters2009-139\"><span>[</span>138<span>]</span></a></sup> Technology jobs accounted for just 1 percent of San Francisco's economy in 1990, growing to 4 percent in 2010 and an estimated 8 percent by the end of 2013.<sup id=\"cite_ref-144\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-144\"><span>[</span>143<span>]</span></a></sup> San Francisco became an epicenter of Internet <a href=\"/wiki/Startup_company\" title=\"Startup company\">start-up companies</a> during the <a href=\"/wiki/Dot-com_bubble\" title=\"Dot-com bubble\">dot-com bubble</a> of the 1990s and the subsequent <a href=\"/wiki/Social_media\" title=\"Social media\">social media</a> boom of the late 2000s.<sup id=\"cite_ref-145\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-145\"><span>[</span>144<span>]</span></a></sup> Since 2010, San Francisco proper has attracted an increasing share of venture capital investments as compared to nearby <a href=\"/wiki/Silicon_Valley\" title=\"Silicon Valley\">Silicon Valley</a>, attracting 423 financings worth US$4.58 billion in 2013.<sup id=\"cite_ref-146\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-146\"><span>[</span>145<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-147\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-147\"><span>[</span>146<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-148\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-148\"><span>[</span>147<span>]</span></a></sup> In 2004, the city approved a payroll tax exemption for biotechnology companies<sup id=\"cite_ref-149\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-149\"><span>[</span>148<span>]</span></a></sup> to foster growth in the <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_Bay,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Mission Bay, San Francisco\">Mission Bay</a> neighborhood, site of a second campus and hospital of the <a href=\"/wiki/University_of_California,_San_Francisco\" title=\"University of California, San Francisco\">University of California, San Francisco</a> (UCSF). Mission Bay hosts the <a href=\"/wiki/California_Institute_for_Regenerative_Medicine\" title=\"California Institute for Regenerative Medicine\">California Institute for Regenerative Medicine</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/California_Institute_for_Quantitative_Biosciences\" title=\"California Institute for Quantitative Biosciences\" class=\"mw-redirect\">California Institute for Quantitative Biosciences</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Gladstone_Institutes\" title=\"Gladstone Institutes\">Gladstone Institutes</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-150\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-150\"><span>[</span>149<span>]</span></a></sup> as well as more than 40 private-sector life sciences companies.<sup id=\"cite_ref-151\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-151\"><span>[</span>150<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:302px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:San_Francisco_from_Pier_7_September_2013_panorama_edit.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/San_Francisco_from_Pier_7_September_2013_panorama_edit.jpg/300px-San_Francisco_from_Pier_7_September_2013_panorama_edit.jpg\" width=\"300\" height=\"113\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/San_Francisco_from_Pier_7_September_2013_panorama_edit.jpg/450px-San_Francisco_from_Pier_7_September_2013_panorama_edit.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/7/7d/San_Francisco_from_Pier_7_September_2013_panorama_edit.jpg/600px-San_Francisco_from_Pier_7_September_2013_panorama_edit.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"6720\" data-file-height=\"2520\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:San_Francisco_from_Pier_7_September_2013_panorama_edit.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nShips docked at Pier 3, with <a href=\"/wiki/Financial_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Financial District, San Francisco\">Financial District</a> skyscrapers in the background.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The top employer in the city is the city government itself, employing 5.3% (25,000+ people) of the city's population, followed by UCSF with over 22,000 employees. Third\u2014at 1.8% (8,500+ people)\u2014is <a href=\"/wiki/California_Pacific_Medical_Center\" title=\"California Pacific Medical Center\">California Pacific Medical Center</a>, the largest private-sector employer.<sup id=\"cite_ref-cafr2014_152-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-cafr2014-152\"><span>[</span>151<span>]</span></a></sup> Small businesses with fewer than 10 employees and self-employed firms make up 85% of city establishments,<sup id=\"cite_ref-153\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-153\"><span>[</span>152<span>]</span></a></sup> and the number of San Franciscans employed by firms of more than 1,000 employees has fallen by half since 1977.<sup id=\"cite_ref-SFEconomicStrategy_154-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SFEconomicStrategy-154\"><span>[</span>153<span>]</span></a></sup> The growth of national <a href=\"/wiki/Big-box_store\" title=\"Big-box store\">big box</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Formula_retail\" title=\"Formula retail\" class=\"mw-redirect\">formula retail</a> chains into the city has been made intentionally difficult by political and civic consensus. In an effort to buoy small privately owned businesses in San Francisco and preserve the unique retail personality of the city, the Small Business Commission supports a publicity campaign to keep a larger share of retail dollars in the local economy,<sup id=\"cite_ref-155\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-155\"><span>[</span>154<span>]</span></a></sup> and the Board of Supervisors has used the planning code to limit the neighborhoods where formula retail establishments can set up shop,<sup id=\"cite_ref-156\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-156\"><span>[</span>155<span>]</span></a></sup> an effort affirmed by San Francisco voters.<sup id=\"cite_ref-157\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-157\"><span>[</span>156<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Manufacturing_in_the_United_States\" title=\"Manufacturing in the United States\">Like many U.S. cities</a>, San Francisco once had a significant manufacturing sector employing nearly 60,000 workers in 1969, but nearly all production left for cheaper locations by the 1980s.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Frojo2014_158-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Frojo2014-158\"><span>[</span>157<span>]</span></a></sup> As of 2014, San Francisco has seen a small resurgence in manufacturing, with more than 4,000 manufacturing jobs across 500 companies, doubling since 2011. The city's largest manufacturing employer is <a href=\"/wiki/Anchor_Brewing_Company\" title=\"Anchor Brewing Company\">Anchor Brewing Company</a>, and the largest by revenue is <a href=\"/wiki/Timbuk2\" title=\"Timbuk2\">Timbuk2</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Frojo2014_158-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Frojo2014-158\"><span>[</span>157<span>]</span></a></sup></p>"},{"toclevel":1,"level":"2","line":"Culture and contemporary life","number":"5","index":"11","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Culture_and_contemporary_life","id":11,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a href=\"/wiki/Culture_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Culture of San Francisco\">Culture of San Francisco</a></div>\n<div class=\"hatnote boilerplate seealso\">See also: <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_in_popular_culture\" title=\"San Francisco in popular culture\">San Francisco in popular culture</a></div>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Fillmore-sidewalk-1.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Fillmore-sidewalk-1.jpg/220px-Fillmore-sidewalk-1.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"165\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Fillmore-sidewalk-1.jpg/330px-Fillmore-sidewalk-1.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Fillmore-sidewalk-1.jpg/440px-Fillmore-sidewalk-1.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"2032\" data-file-height=\"1524\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Fillmore-sidewalk-1.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nBoutiques along <a href=\"/wiki/Fillmore_Street\" title=\"Fillmore Street\">Fillmore Street</a> in <a href=\"/wiki/Pacific_Heights,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Pacific Heights, San Francisco\">Pacific Heights</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Although the <a href=\"/wiki/Financial_District_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Financial District (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Financial District</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Union_Square,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Union Square, San Francisco\">Union Square</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Fisherman%27s_Wharf,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco\">Fisherman's Wharf</a> are well-known around the world, San Francisco is also characterized by its numerous culturally rich streetscapes featuring <a href=\"/wiki/Mixed-use_development\" title=\"Mixed-use development\">mixed-use</a> neighborhoods anchored around <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_streets_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of streets in San Francisco\">central commercial corridors</a> to which residents and visitors alike can walk. Because of these characteristics, San Francisco is ranked the second \"most walkable\" city in the U.S. by Walkscore.com.<sup id=\"cite_ref-159\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-159\"><span>[</span>158<span>]</span></a></sup> Many neighborhoods feature a mix of businesses, restaurants and venues that cater to both the daily needs of local residents while also serving many visitors and tourists. Some neighborhoods are dotted with boutiques, cafes and nightlife such as Union Street in <a href=\"/wiki/Cow_Hollow,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Cow Hollow, San Francisco\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Cow Hollow</a>, 24th Street in <a href=\"/wiki/Noe_Valley,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Noe Valley, San Francisco\">Noe Valley</a>, Valencia Street in the <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Mission District, San Francisco\">Mission</a>, and Irving Street in the <a href=\"/wiki/Sunset_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Sunset District, San Francisco\">Inner Sunset</a>. This approach especially has influenced the continuing South of Market neighborhood redevelopment with businesses and neighborhood services rising alongside high-rise residences.<sup id=\"cite_ref-FogDev_160-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FogDev-160\"><span>[</span>159<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:South_of_Market,_San_Francisco.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/South_of_Market%2C_San_Francisco.jpg/220px-South_of_Market%2C_San_Francisco.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"147\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/South_of_Market%2C_San_Francisco.jpg/330px-South_of_Market%2C_San_Francisco.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/6/65/South_of_Market%2C_San_Francisco.jpg/440px-South_of_Market%2C_San_Francisco.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"1500\" data-file-height=\"1000\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:South_of_Market,_San_Francisco.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nHigh-rises surround <a href=\"/wiki/Yerba_Buena_Gardens\" title=\"Yerba Buena Gardens\">Yerba Buena Gardens</a>, South of Market</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Since the 1990s, the demand for skilled <a href=\"/wiki/Information_technology\" title=\"Information technology\">information technology</a> workers from local startups and nearby <a href=\"/wiki/Silicon_Valley\" title=\"Silicon Valley\">Silicon Valley</a> has attracted <a href=\"/wiki/White-collar_worker\" title=\"White-collar worker\">white-collar workers</a> from all over the world and created a high standard of living in San Francisco.<sup id=\"cite_ref-161\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-161\"><span>[</span>160<span>]</span></a></sup> Many neighborhoods that were once <a href=\"/wiki/Blue-collar\" title=\"Blue-collar\" class=\"mw-redirect\">blue-collar</a>, middle, and lower class have been <a href=\"/wiki/Gentrification\" title=\"Gentrification\">gentrifying</a>, as many of the city's traditional business and industrial districts have experienced a renaissance driven by the redevelopment of the <a href=\"/wiki/The_Embarcadero_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"The Embarcadero (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Embarcadero</a>, including the neighborhoods <a href=\"/wiki/South_Beach,_San_Francisco\" title=\"South Beach, San Francisco\" class=\"mw-redirect\">South Beach</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_Bay,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Mission Bay, San Francisco\">Mission Bay</a>. The city's property values and household income have risen to among the highest in the nation,<sup id=\"cite_ref-162\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-162\"><span>[</span>161<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-MedianIncome_163-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-MedianIncome-163\"><span>[</span>162<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-164\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-164\"><span>[</span>163<span>]</span></a></sup> creating a large and upscale restaurant, retail, and entertainment scene. According to a 2008 quality of life survey of global cities, San Francisco has the second <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_cities_by_quality_of_living\" title=\"List of cities by quality of living\" class=\"mw-redirect\">highest quality of living</a> of any U.S. city.<sup id=\"cite_ref-165\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-165\"><span>[</span>164<span>]</span></a></sup> However, due to the exceptionally high cost of living, many of the city's middle and lower-class families have been leaving the city for the outer suburbs of the Bay Area, or for California's <a href=\"/wiki/Central_Valley_(California)\" title=\"Central Valley (California)\">Central Valley</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-MiddleClass_119-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-MiddleClass-119\"><span>[</span>118<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>The international character that San Francisco has enjoyed since its founding is continued today by large numbers of immigrants from Asia and Latin America. With 39% of its residents born overseas,<sup id=\"cite_ref-SFEconomicStrategy_154-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SFEconomicStrategy-154\"><span>[</span>153<span>]</span></a></sup> San Francisco has numerous neighborhoods filled with businesses and civic institutions catering to new arrivals. In particular, the arrival of many ethnic Chinese, which accelerated beginning in the 1970s, has complemented the long-established community historically based in <a href=\"/wiki/Chinatown,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Chinatown, San Francisco\">Chinatown</a> throughout the city and has transformed the annual <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Chinese_New_Year_Festival_and_Parade\" title=\"San Francisco Chinese New Year Festival and Parade\">Chinese New Year Parade</a> into the largest event of its kind outside China.<sup id=\"cite_ref-166\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-166\"><span>[</span>165<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:172px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Castro_Rainbow_Flag.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Castro_Rainbow_Flag.jpg/170px-Castro_Rainbow_Flag.jpg\" width=\"170\" height=\"227\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Castro_Rainbow_Flag.jpg/255px-Castro_Rainbow_Flag.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/54/Castro_Rainbow_Flag.jpg/340px-Castro_Rainbow_Flag.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"1536\" data-file-height=\"2048\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Castro_Rainbow_Flag.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe <a href=\"/wiki/Rainbow_flag_(LGBT_movement)\" title=\"Rainbow flag (LGBT movement)\">rainbow flag</a>, symbol of <a href=\"/wiki/LGBT\" title=\"LGBT\">LGBT</a> pride, originated in San Francisco; banners like this one decorate streets in <a href=\"/wiki/The_Castro,_San_Francisco\" title=\"The Castro, San Francisco\">The Castro</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Castro_Street_with_Rainbow_Ped_Crossing.JPG\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Castro_Street_with_Rainbow_Ped_Crossing.JPG/220px-Castro_Street_with_Rainbow_Ped_Crossing.JPG\" width=\"220\" height=\"165\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Castro_Street_with_Rainbow_Ped_Crossing.JPG/330px-Castro_Street_with_Rainbow_Ped_Crossing.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/8/89/Castro_Street_with_Rainbow_Ped_Crossing.JPG/440px-Castro_Street_with_Rainbow_Ped_Crossing.JPG 2x\" data-file-width=\"4000\" data-file-height=\"3000\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Castro_Street_with_Rainbow_Ped_Crossing.JPG\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nCastro Street Ped Xing with Rainbow Flag Colors Strips</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>With the arrival of the <a href=\"/wiki/Beat_Generation\" title=\"Beat Generation\">\"beat\"</a> writers and artists of the 1950s and societal changes culminating in the <a href=\"/wiki/Summer_of_Love\" title=\"Summer of Love\">Summer of Love</a> in the <a href=\"/wiki/Haight-Ashbury\" title=\"Haight-Ashbury\">Haight-Ashbury</a> district during the 1960s, San Francisco became a center of <a href=\"/wiki/Modern_liberalism_in_the_United_States\" title=\"Modern liberalism in the United States\">liberal</a> activism and of the <a href=\"/wiki/Counterculture\" title=\"Counterculture\">counterculture</a> that arose at that time. The <a href=\"/wiki/Democratic_Party_(United_States)\" title=\"Democratic Party (United States)\">Democrats</a> and to a lesser extent the <a href=\"/wiki/Green_Party_(United_States)\" title=\"Green Party (United States)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Green Party</a> have dominated <a href=\"/wiki/Politics_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Politics of San Francisco\">city politics</a> since the late 1970s, after the <a href=\"/wiki/John_Barbagelata\" title=\"John Barbagelata\">last serious</a> <a href=\"/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)\" title=\"Republican Party (United States)\">Republican</a> challenger for city office <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_mayoral_election,_1975\" title=\"San Francisco mayoral election, 1975\">lost the 1975 mayoral election</a> by a narrow margin. San Francisco has not voted more than 20% for a <a href=\"/wiki/Republican_Party_(United_States)\" title=\"Republican Party (United States)\">Republican</a> presidential or senatorial candidate since <a href=\"/wiki/United_States_presidential_election,_1988\" title=\"United States presidential election, 1988\">1988</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-167\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-167\"><span>[</span>166<span>]</span></a></sup> In 2007, the city expanded its <a href=\"/wiki/Medicaid\" title=\"Medicaid\">Medicaid</a> and other <a href=\"/wiki/Indigent\" title=\"Indigent\" class=\"mw-redirect\">indigent</a> medical programs into the \"<a href=\"/wiki/Healthy_San_Francisco\" title=\"Healthy San Francisco\">Healthy San Francisco</a>\" program,<sup id=\"cite_ref-168\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-168\"><span>[</span>167<span>]</span></a></sup> which <a href=\"/wiki/Subsidy\" title=\"Subsidy\">subsidizes</a> certain medical services for eligible residents.<sup id=\"cite_ref-169\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-169\"><span>[</span>168<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-170\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-170\"><span>[</span>169<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-171\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-171\"><span>[</span>170<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>San Francisco has long had an <a href=\"/wiki/LGBT\" title=\"LGBT\">LGBT</a>-friendly <a href=\"/wiki/LGBT_culture_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"LGBT culture in San Francisco\">history</a>. It was home to the first lesbian-rights organization in the United States, <a href=\"/wiki/Daughters_of_Bilitis\" title=\"Daughters of Bilitis\">Daughters of Bilitis</a>; the first openly gay person to run for public office in the U.S., <a href=\"/wiki/Jos%C3%A9_Sarria\" title=\"Jos\u00e9 Sarria\">Jos\u00e9 Sarria</a>; the first openly gay man to be elected to public office in the U.S., <a href=\"/wiki/Harvey_Milk\" title=\"Harvey Milk\">Harvey Milk</a>; the first openly lesbian judge appointed in the U.S., <a href=\"/wiki/Mary_C._Morgan\" title=\"Mary C. Morgan\">Mary C. Morgan</a>; and the first <a href=\"/wiki/Transgender\" title=\"Transgender\">transgender</a> police commissioner, <a href=\"/wiki/Theresa_Sparks\" title=\"Theresa Sparks\">Theresa Sparks</a>. The city's large gay population has created and sustained a politically and culturally active community over many decades, developing a powerful presence in San Francisco's civic life. One of the most popular destinations for gay tourists internationally, the city hosts <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Pride\" title=\"San Francisco Pride\">San Francisco Pride</a>, one of the largest and oldest <a href=\"/wiki/Pride_parades\" title=\"Pride parades\" class=\"mw-redirect\">pride parades</a>.</p>\n<p>San Francisco also has had a very active environmental community. Starting with the founding of the <a href=\"/wiki/Sierra_Club\" title=\"Sierra Club\">Sierra Club</a> in 1892 to the establishment of the non-profit <a href=\"/wiki/Friends_of_the_Urban_Forest\" title=\"Friends of the Urban Forest\">Friends of the Urban Forest</a> in 1981, San Francisco has been at the forefront of many global discussions regarding our natural environment.<sup id=\"cite_ref-172\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-172\"><span>[</span>171<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-173\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-173\"><span>[</span>172<span>]</span></a></sup> The 1980 <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Mandatory_Recycling_and_Composting_Ordinance\" title=\"San Francisco Mandatory Recycling and Composting Ordinance\">San Francisco Recycling Program</a> was one of the earliest curbside recycling programs.<sup id=\"cite_ref-174\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-174\"><span>[</span>173<span>]</span></a></sup> The city's GoSolarSF incentive promotes solar installations and the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Public_Utilities_Commission\" title=\"San Francisco Public Utilities Commission\">San Francisco Public Utilities Commission</a> is rolling out the <a href=\"/wiki/CleanPowerSF\" title=\"CleanPowerSF\">CleanPowerSF</a> program to sell electricity from local renewable sources.<sup id=\"cite_ref-175\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-175\"><span>[</span>174<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-176\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-176\"><span>[</span>175<span>]</span></a></sup> SF Greasecycle is a program to recycle used cooking oil for conversion to biodiesel.<sup id=\"cite_ref-177\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-177\"><span>[</span>176<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>The newly completed <a href=\"/wiki/Sunset_Reservoir\" title=\"Sunset Reservoir\">Sunset Reservoir</a> Solar Project has installed 25,000 solar panels on the 480,000&#160;sq&#160;ft (45,000&#160;m<sup>2</sup>) roof of the reservoir. The 5-megawatt plant more than tripled the city's 2-megawatt solar generation capacity when it opened in December 2010.<sup id=\"cite_ref-178\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-178\"><span>[</span>177<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-179\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-179\"><span>[</span>178<span>]</span></a></sup></p>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Entertainment and performing arts","number":"5.1","index":"12","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Entertainment_and_performing_arts","id":12,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_theatres_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of theatres in San Francisco\">List of theatres in San Francisco</a></div>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SFWMOHLobbySouth.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/SFWMOHLobbySouth.jpg/220px-SFWMOHLobbySouth.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"200\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/SFWMOHLobbySouth.jpg/330px-SFWMOHLobbySouth.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/f/fe/SFWMOHLobbySouth.jpg/440px-SFWMOHLobbySouth.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"1100\" data-file-height=\"1000\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SFWMOHLobbySouth.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe lobby of the <a href=\"/wiki/War_Memorial_Opera_House_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"War Memorial Opera House (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">War Memorial Opera House</a>, one of the last buildings erected in <a href=\"/wiki/Beaux-Arts_architecture\" title=\"Beaux-Arts architecture\">Beaux Arts</a> style in the United States</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>San Francisco's <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_War_Memorial_and_Performing_Arts_Center\" title=\"San Francisco War Memorial and Performing Arts Center\">War Memorial and Performing Arts Center</a> hosts some of the most enduring performing-arts companies in the U.S. The <a href=\"/wiki/War_Memorial_Opera_House\" title=\"War Memorial Opera House\">War Memorial Opera House</a> houses the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Opera\" title=\"San Francisco Opera\">San Francisco Opera</a>, the second-largest opera company in North America<sup id=\"cite_ref-180\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-180\"><span>[</span>179<span>]</span></a></sup> as well as the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Ballet\" title=\"San Francisco Ballet\">San Francisco Ballet</a>, while the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Symphony\" title=\"San Francisco Symphony\">San Francisco Symphony</a> plays in <a href=\"/wiki/Louise_M._Davies_Symphony_Hall\" title=\"Louise M. Davies Symphony Hall\">Davies Symphony Hall</a>. The <a href=\"/wiki/Herbst_Theatre\" title=\"Herbst Theatre\">Herbst Theatre</a> stages an eclectic mix of music performances, as well as <a href=\"/wiki/National_Public_Radio\" title=\"National Public Radio\" class=\"mw-redirect\">public radio</a>'s <i><a href=\"/wiki/City_Arts_%26_Lectures\" title=\"City Arts &amp; Lectures\">City Arts &amp; Lectures</a>.</i></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/The_Fillmore\" title=\"The Fillmore\">The Fillmore</a> is a music venue located in the <a href=\"/wiki/Western_Addition,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Western Addition, San Francisco\">Western Addition</a>. It is the second incarnation of the historic venue that gained fame in the 1960s under concert promoter <a href=\"/wiki/Bill_Graham_(promoter)\" title=\"Bill Graham (promoter)\">Bill Graham</a>, housing the stage where now-famous musicians such as the <a href=\"/wiki/Grateful_Dead\" title=\"Grateful Dead\">Grateful Dead</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Janis_Joplin\" title=\"Janis Joplin\">Janis Joplin</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Led_Zeppelin\" title=\"Led Zeppelin\">Led Zeppelin</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Jefferson_Airplane\" title=\"Jefferson Airplane\">Jefferson Airplane</a> first performed, fostering the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Sound\" title=\"San Francisco Sound\">San Francisco Sound</a>. <i><a href=\"/wiki/Beach_Blanket_Babylon\" title=\"Beach Blanket Babylon\">Beach Blanket Babylon</a></i> is a zany musical revue and a civic institution that has performed to sold-out crowds in <a href=\"/wiki/North_Beach,_San_Francisco\" title=\"North Beach, San Francisco\">North Beach</a> since 1974.</p>\n<p>Comedian and actor, <a href=\"/wiki/Robin_Williams\" title=\"Robin Williams\">Robin Williams</a> helped San Francisco become recognized as a good town for comedy clubs. He rose to fame, having gotten his early start in San Francisco clubs such as the <a href=\"/wiki/Holy_City_Zoo\" title=\"Holy City Zoo\">Holy City Zoo</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/The_Punchline\" title=\"The Punchline\" class=\"mw-redirect\">the Punchline</a> and the Other Cafe in the '70's.<sup id=\"cite_ref-sfexaminer.com_181-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-sfexaminer.com-181\"><span>[</span>180<span>]</span></a></sup> He also shot seven films on location in San Francisco.<sup id=\"cite_ref-sfexaminer.com_181-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-sfexaminer.com-181\"><span>[</span>180<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>The <a href=\"/wiki/American_Conservatory_Theater\" title=\"American Conservatory Theater\">American Conservatory Theater</a> (A.C.T.) has been a force in Bay Area performing arts since its arrival in San Francisco in 1967, regularly staging productions. San Francisco frequently hosts national touring productions of Broadway theatre shows in a number of vintage 1920s-era venues in the <a href=\"/wiki/Theater_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Theater District, San Francisco\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Theater District</a> including the <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_theatres_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of theatres in San Francisco\">Curran</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_theatres_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of theatres in San Francisco\">Orpheum</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_theatres_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of theatres in San Francisco\">Golden Gate</a> Theatres.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art_in_2011.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art_in_2011.jpg/220px-San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art_in_2011.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"147\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art_in_2011.jpg/330px-San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art_in_2011.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ef/San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art_in_2011.jpg/440px-San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art_in_2011.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"2995\" data-file-height=\"2000\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art_in_2011.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe red brick and central circular structure of the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art\" title=\"San Francisco Museum of Modern Art\">San Francisco Museum of Modern Art</a> as seen from <a href=\"/wiki/Yerba_Buena_Gardens\" title=\"Yerba Buena Gardens\">Yerba Buena Gardens</a>. The <a href=\"/wiki/Art_Deco\" title=\"Art Deco\">Art Deco</a>-style <a href=\"/wiki/140_New_Montgomery\" title=\"140 New Montgomery\">Pacific Telephone Building</a> (1925) rises behind the museum.</div>\n</div>\n</div>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Museums","number":"5.2","index":"13","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Museums","id":13,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_museums_in_San_Francisco_Bay_Area,_California#San_Francisco\" title=\"List of museums in San Francisco Bay Area, California\" class=\"mw-redirect\">List of museums in San Francisco Bay Area, California \u00a7 San Francisco</a></div>\n<p>The <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Museum_of_Modern_Art\" title=\"San Francisco Museum of Modern Art\">San Francisco Museum of Modern Art</a> (SFMOMA) houses 20th century and contemporary works of art. It moved to its current building in the <a href=\"/wiki/South_of_Market,_San_Francisco\" title=\"South of Market, San Francisco\">South of Market</a> neighborhood in 1995 and now attracts more than 600,000 visitors annually.<sup id=\"cite_ref-182\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-182\"><span>[</span>181<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/California_Palace_of_the_Legion_of_Honor\" title=\"California Palace of the Legion of Honor\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Palace of the Legion of Honor</a> holds primarily European antiquities and works of art at its <a href=\"/wiki/Lincoln_Park_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Lincoln Park (San Francisco)\">Lincoln Park</a> building modeled after its <a href=\"/wiki/Palais_de_la_L%C3%A9gion_d%27Honneur\" title=\"Palais de la L\u00e9gion d'Honneur\">Parisian namesake</a>. It is administered by <a href=\"/wiki/Fine_Arts_Museums_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco\">Fine Arts Museums of San Francisco</a>, which also operates the <a href=\"/wiki/M._H._de_Young_Memorial_Museum\" title=\"M. H. de Young Memorial Museum\" class=\"mw-redirect\">de Young Museum</a> in Golden Gate Park. The de Young's collection features American decorative pieces and anthropological holdings from Africa, Oceania and the Americas. Prior to construction of its current copper-clad structure, completed in 2005, the de Young also housed the <a href=\"/wiki/Asian_Art_Museum_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Asian Art Museum of San Francisco\">Asian Art Museum</a>, which, with artifacts from over 6,000&#160;years of history across Asia, moved into the former <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Public_Library\" title=\"San Francisco Public Library\">public library</a> next to <a href=\"/wiki/Civic_Center,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Civic Center, San Francisco\">Civic Center</a> in 2003.</p>\n<p>Opposite the <a href=\"/wiki/Music_Concourse\" title=\"Music Concourse\">Music Concourse</a> from the de Young stands the <a href=\"/wiki/California_Academy_of_Sciences\" title=\"California Academy of Sciences\">California Academy of Sciences</a>, a natural history museum that also hosts the <a href=\"/wiki/Morrison_Planetarium\" title=\"Morrison Planetarium\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Morrison Planetarium</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Steinhart_Aquarium\" title=\"Steinhart Aquarium\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Steinhart Aquarium</a>. Its current structure, featuring a <a href=\"/wiki/Living_roof\" title=\"Living roof\" class=\"mw-redirect\">living roof</a>, is an example of <a href=\"/wiki/Sustainable_architecture\" title=\"Sustainable architecture\">sustainable architecture</a> and opened in 2008. Located on Pier 15 on the Embarcadero, the <a href=\"/wiki/Exploratorium\" title=\"Exploratorium\">Exploratorium</a> is an interactive science museum founded by physicist <a href=\"/wiki/Frank_Oppenheimer\" title=\"Frank Oppenheimer\">Frank Oppenheimer</a> in 1969. Two museum ships are moored near Fisherman's Wharf, the <a href=\"/wiki/SS_Jeremiah_O%27Brien\" title=\"SS Jeremiah O'Brien\">SS <i>Jeremiah O'Brien</i></a> Liberty ship and <a href=\"/wiki/USS_Pampanito_(SS-383)\" title=\"USS Pampanito (SS-383)\">USS <i>Pampanito</i></a> submarine. On Nob Hill, the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Cable_Car_Museum\" title=\"San Francisco Cable Car Museum\">Cable Car Museum</a> is a working museum featuring the cable car power house, which drives the cables, and the car depot.</p>"},{"toclevel":1,"level":"2","line":"Sports and recreation","number":"6","index":"14","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Sports_and_recreation","id":14,"text":"<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:AT%26T_Park.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/AT%26T_Park.jpg/220px-AT%26T_Park.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"165\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/AT%26T_Park.jpg/330px-AT%26T_Park.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/2/2a/AT%26T_Park.jpg/440px-AT%26T_Park.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"2272\" data-file-height=\"1704\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:AT%26T_Park.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\n<a href=\"/wiki/AT%26T_Park\" title=\"AT&amp;T Park\">AT&amp;T Park</a> opened in 2000.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a href=\"/wiki/Sports_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"Sports in San Francisco\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Sports in San Francisco</a></div>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Major_League_Baseball\" title=\"Major League Baseball\">Major League Baseball</a>'s <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Giants\" title=\"San Francisco Giants\">San Francisco Giants</a> left New York for California prior to the 1958 season. Though boasting such stars as <a href=\"/wiki/Willie_Mays\" title=\"Willie Mays\">Willie Mays</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Willie_McCovey\" title=\"Willie McCovey\">Willie McCovey</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Barry_Bonds\" title=\"Barry Bonds\">Barry Bonds</a>, the club went 52 years until its first <a href=\"/wiki/World_Series\" title=\"World Series\">World Series</a> title in <a href=\"/wiki/2010_World_Series\" title=\"2010 World Series\">2010</a>, and won an additional title in <a href=\"/wiki/2012_World_Series\" title=\"2012 World Series\">2012</a>. The Giants play at <a href=\"/wiki/AT%26T_Park\" title=\"AT&amp;T Park\">AT&amp;T Park</a>, which opened in 2000, a cornerstone project of the <a href=\"/wiki/South_Beach,_San_Francisco\" title=\"South Beach, San Francisco\" class=\"mw-redirect\">South Beach</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_Bay,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Mission Bay, San Francisco\">Mission Bay</a> redevelopment.<sup id=\"cite_ref-183\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-183\"><span>[</span>182<span>]</span></a></sup> In 2012, San Francisco was ranked #1 among America's Best Baseball cities. The study examined which U.S. metro areas have produced the most Major Leaguers since 1920.<sup id=\"cite_ref-184\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-184\"><span>[</span>183<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Candlestick_Park_aerial.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Candlestick_Park_aerial.jpg/220px-Candlestick_Park_aerial.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"159\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Candlestick_Park_aerial.jpg/330px-Candlestick_Park_aerial.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/0/0e/Candlestick_Park_aerial.jpg/440px-Candlestick_Park_aerial.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"5552\" data-file-height=\"4015\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Candlestick_Park_aerial.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\n<a href=\"/wiki/Candlestick_Park\" title=\"Candlestick Park\">Candlestick Park</a> hosted the Giants from 1960\u201399 and the 49ers from 1971\u20132013.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_49ers\" title=\"San Francisco 49ers\">San Francisco 49ers</a> of the <a href=\"/wiki/National_Football_League\" title=\"National Football League\">National Football League</a> (NFL) were the longest-tenured major professional sports franchise in the city. The team began play in 1946 as an <a href=\"/wiki/All-America_Football_Conference\" title=\"All-America Football Conference\">All-America Football Conference</a> (AAFC) league charter member, moved to the NFL in 1950 and into <a href=\"/wiki/Candlestick_Park\" title=\"Candlestick Park\">Candlestick Park</a> in 1971. The team began playing its home games at <a href=\"/wiki/Levi%27s_Stadium\" title=\"Levi's Stadium\">Levi's Stadium</a> in <a href=\"/wiki/Santa_Clara,_California\" title=\"Santa Clara, California\">Santa Clara, California</a> in 2014; the team is still named the \"San Francisco 49ers\", even though they are much closer to the city of <a href=\"/wiki/San_Jose,_California\" title=\"San Jose, California\">San Jose</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-185\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-185\"><span>[</span>184<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-186\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-186\"><span>[</span>185<span>]</span></a></sup> The 49ers have won five <a href=\"/wiki/Super_Bowl\" title=\"Super Bowl\">Super Bowl</a> titles in the 1980s and 1990s behind coaches <a href=\"/wiki/Bill_Walsh_(American_football_coach)\" title=\"Bill Walsh (American football coach)\">Bill Walsh</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/George_Seifert\" title=\"George Seifert\">George Seifert</a>, and stars such as <a href=\"/wiki/Joe_Montana\" title=\"Joe Montana\">Joe Montana</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Steve_Young_(athlete)\" title=\"Steve Young (athlete)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Steve Young</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Ronnie_Lott\" title=\"Ronnie Lott\">Ronnie Lott</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Jerry_Rice\" title=\"Jerry Rice\">Jerry Rice</a>.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:USF_WMG.JPG\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/USF_WMG.JPG/220px-USF_WMG.JPG\" width=\"220\" height=\"165\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/USF_WMG.JPG/330px-USF_WMG.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/a/ae/USF_WMG.JPG/440px-USF_WMG.JPG 2x\" data-file-width=\"640\" data-file-height=\"480\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:USF_WMG.JPG\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe <a href=\"/wiki/University_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"University of San Francisco\">University of San Francisco</a> Dons men's basketball team plays at the <a href=\"/wiki/War_Memorial_Gymnasium\" title=\"War Memorial Gymnasium\">War Memorial Gymnasium</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>At the collegiate level, the Dons of the <a href=\"/wiki/University_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"University of San Francisco\">University of San Francisco</a> compete in <a href=\"/wiki/NCAA\" title=\"NCAA\" class=\"mw-redirect\">NCAA</a> <a href=\"/wiki/NCAA_Division_I\" title=\"NCAA Division I\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Division I</a>, where <a href=\"/wiki/Bill_Russell\" title=\"Bill Russell\">Bill Russell</a> guided the program to <a href=\"/wiki/NCAA_Men%27s_Division_I_Basketball_Championship\" title=\"NCAA Men's Division I Basketball Championship\">basketball championships</a> in 1955 and 1956. The <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_State_University\" title=\"San Francisco State University\">San Francisco State</a> Gators and the <a href=\"/wiki/Academy_of_Art_University\" title=\"Academy of Art University\">Academy of Art University</a> Urban Knights compete in <a href=\"/wiki/NCAA_Division_II\" title=\"NCAA Division II\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Division II</a>. AT&amp;T Park has since 2002 hosted an annual post-season <a href=\"/wiki/College_football\" title=\"College football\">college football</a> <a href=\"/wiki/Bowl_game\" title=\"Bowl game\">bowl game</a>, currently named the <a href=\"/wiki/Fight_Hunger_Bowl\" title=\"Fight Hunger Bowl\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Fight Hunger Bowl</a>. In 2011, San Francisco hosted the <a href=\"/wiki/2011_California_Golden_Bears_football_team\" title=\"2011 California Golden Bears football team\">California Golden Bears</a> football team at Candlestick Park and AT&amp;T Park while their home stadium in Berkeley was being renovated.</p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Pro-Am_Basketball_League\" title=\"San Francisco Pro-Am Basketball League\">San Francisco Pro-Am Basketball League</a> is an important summer league venue for aspiring players to be discovered by talent scouts. Games are held at the 4,000 seat <a href=\"/wiki/Kezar_Pavilion\" title=\"Kezar Pavilion\">Kezar Pavilion</a>. Players from all levels participate with regular appearances by off season NBA professionals.<sup id=\"cite_ref-187\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-187\"><span>[</span>186<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>The <a href=\"/wiki/Bay_to_Breakers\" title=\"Bay to Breakers\">Bay to Breakers</a> footrace, held annually since 1912, is best known for colorful costumes and a celebratory community spirit.<sup id=\"cite_ref-188\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-188\"><span>[</span>187<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Marathon\" title=\"San Francisco Marathon\">San Francisco Marathon</a> attracts more than 21,000 participants.<sup id=\"cite_ref-189\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-189\"><span>[</span>188<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/Escape_from_Alcatraz_(triathlon)\" title=\"Escape from Alcatraz (triathlon)\">Escape from Alcatraz</a> <a href=\"/wiki/Triathlon\" title=\"Triathlon\">triathlon</a> has, since 1980, attracted 2,000 top professional and amateur triathletes for its annual race.<sup id=\"cite_ref-190\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-190\"><span>[</span>189<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/Olympic_Club\" title=\"Olympic Club\">Olympic Club</a>, founded in 1860, is the oldest <a href=\"/wiki/Sports_club\" title=\"Sports club\">athletic club</a> in the United States. Its private golf course, situated on the border with <a href=\"/wiki/Daly_City,_California\" title=\"Daly City, California\">Daly City</a>, has hosted the <a href=\"/wiki/U.S._Open_(golf)\" title=\"U.S. Open (golf)\">U.S. Open</a> on five occasions. The public <a href=\"/wiki/Harding_Park_Golf_Course\" title=\"Harding Park Golf Course\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Harding Park Golf Course</a> is an occasional stop on the <a href=\"/wiki/PGA_Tour\" title=\"PGA Tour\">PGA Tour</a>. San Francisco hosted the <a href=\"/wiki/2013_America%27s_Cup\" title=\"2013 America's Cup\">2013 America's Cup</a> yacht racing competition.<sup id=\"cite_ref-191\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-191\"><span>[</span>190<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>With an ideal climate for outdoor activities, San Francisco has ample resources and opportunities for amateur and participatory sports and recreation. There are more than 200 miles (320&#160;km) of <a href=\"/wiki/Segregated_cycle_facilities\" title=\"Segregated cycle facilities\">bicycle paths, lanes</a> and bike routes in the city,<sup id=\"cite_ref-192\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-192\"><span>[</span>191<span>]</span></a></sup> and the <a href=\"/wiki/Embarcadero_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Embarcadero (San Francisco)\">Embarcadero</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Marina_Green\" title=\"Marina Green\">Marina Green</a> are favored sites for <a href=\"/wiki/Skateboarding\" title=\"Skateboarding\">skateboarding</a>. Extensive public tennis facilities are available in <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_Park\" title=\"Golden Gate Park\">Golden Gate Park</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Dolores_Park\" title=\"Dolores Park\">Dolores Park</a>, as well as at smaller neighborhood courts throughout the city. San Francisco residents have often ranked among the fittest in the U.S.<sup id=\"cite_ref-fitness_193-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-fitness-193\"><span>[</span>192<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>Boating, sailing, <a href=\"/wiki/Windsurfing\" title=\"Windsurfing\">windsurfing</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Kitesurfing\" title=\"Kitesurfing\">kitesurfing</a> are among the popular activities on San Francisco Bay, and the city maintains a yacht harbor in the <a href=\"/wiki/Marina_District,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Marina District, San Francisco\">Marina District</a>. The <a href=\"/wiki/St._Francis_Yacht_Club\" title=\"St. Francis Yacht Club\">St. Francis Yacht Club</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_Yacht_Club\" title=\"Golden Gate Yacht Club\">Golden Gate Yacht Club</a> are located in the Marina Harbor.<sup id=\"cite_ref-194\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-194\"><span>[</span>193<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-195\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-195\"><span>[</span>194<span>]</span></a></sup> The South Beach Yacht Club is located next to AT&amp;T Park and <a href=\"/wiki/Pier_39\" title=\"Pier 39\">Pier 39</a> has an extensive marina.<sup id=\"cite_ref-196\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-196\"><span>[</span>195<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-197\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-197\"><span>[</span>196<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Olympic_Club_18th_hole_lakeside.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Olympic_Club_18th_hole_lakeside.jpg/220px-Olympic_Club_18th_hole_lakeside.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"147\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Olympic_Club_18th_hole_lakeside.jpg/330px-Olympic_Club_18th_hole_lakeside.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ee/Olympic_Club_18th_hole_lakeside.jpg/440px-Olympic_Club_18th_hole_lakeside.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"2048\" data-file-height=\"1369\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Olympic_Club_18th_hole_lakeside.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe 18th hole at the <a
