href=\"/wiki/Olympic_Club\" title=\"Olympic Club\">Olympic Club</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Historic <a href=\"/wiki/Aquatic_Park_Historic_District\" title=\"Aquatic Park Historic District\">Aquatic Park</a> located along the northern San Francisco shore hosts two swimming and rowing clubs.<sup id=\"cite_ref-198\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-198\"><span>[</span>197<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-199\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-199\"><span>[</span>198<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/South_End_Rowing_Club\" title=\"South End Rowing Club\">South End Rowing Club</a>, established in 1873, and the Dolphin Club maintain a friendly rivalry between members. Swimmers can be seen daily braving the typically cold bay waters.</p>\n<p>Amateur men's <a href=\"/wiki/Soccer\" title=\"Soccer\" class=\"mw-redirect\">soccer</a> has been played in San Francisco since 1902 through the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Soccer_Football_League\" title=\"San Francisco Soccer Football League\">San Francisco Soccer Football League</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-200\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-200\"><span>[</span>199<span>]</span></a></sup> Over 40 teams in 4 divisions play throughout the city between the months of March and November. Premier Division games are played at the 3,500 seat <a href=\"/wiki/Boxer_Stadium\" title=\"Boxer Stadium\">Boxer Stadium</a>. Amateur women's soccer is played on over 30 teams in the Golden Gate Women's Soccer League.<sup id=\"cite_ref-201\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-201\"><span>[</span>200<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Cycling_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"Cycling in San Francisco\">Cycling</a> is growing in San Francisco. Annual bicycle counts conducted by the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Municipal_Transportation_Agency\" title=\"San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency\">Municipal Transportation Agency (MTA)</a> in 2010 showed the number of cyclists at 33 locations had increased 58% from the 2006 baseline counts.<sup id=\"cite_ref-202\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-202\"><span>[</span>201<span>]</span></a></sup> The MTA estimates that about 128,000 trips are made by bicycle each day in the city, or 6% of total trips.<sup id=\"cite_ref-203\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-203\"><span>[</span>202<span>]</span></a></sup> Improvements in <a href=\"/wiki/Cycling_infrastructure\" title=\"Cycling infrastructure\">cycling infrastructure</a> in recent years, including additional bike lanes and parking racks, has made cycling in San Francisco safer and more convenient. Since 2006, San Francisco has received a Bicycle Friendly Community status of \"Gold\" from the <a href=\"/wiki/League_of_American_Bicyclists\" title=\"League of American Bicyclists\">League of American Bicyclists</a>.</p>"},{"toclevel":1,"level":"2","line":"Beaches and parks","number":"7","index":"15","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Beaches_and_parks","id":15,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote boilerplate seealso\">See also: <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_parks_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of parks in San Francisco\">List of parks in San Francisco</a></div>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Cliff_House_from_Ocean_Beach.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Cliff_House_from_Ocean_Beach.jpg/220px-Cliff_House_from_Ocean_Beach.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"143\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Cliff_House_from_Ocean_Beach.jpg/330px-Cliff_House_from_Ocean_Beach.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Cliff_House_from_Ocean_Beach.jpg/440px-Cliff_House_from_Ocean_Beach.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"2222\" data-file-height=\"1447\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Cliff_House_from_Ocean_Beach.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\n<a href=\"/wiki/Ocean_Beach,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Ocean Beach, San Francisco\">Ocean Beach, San Francisco</a> with a view of the <a href=\"/wiki/Cliff_House_(San_Francisco,_California)\" title=\"Cliff House (San Francisco, California)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Cliff House</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SF_Conservatory_of_Flowers_3.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/SF_Conservatory_of_Flowers_3.jpg/220px-SF_Conservatory_of_Flowers_3.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"165\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/SF_Conservatory_of_Flowers_3.jpg/330px-SF_Conservatory_of_Flowers_3.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4a/SF_Conservatory_of_Flowers_3.jpg/440px-SF_Conservatory_of_Flowers_3.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"1280\" data-file-height=\"960\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SF_Conservatory_of_Flowers_3.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe <a href=\"/wiki/Conservatory_of_Flowers\" title=\"Conservatory of Flowers\">Conservatory of Flowers</a> in <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_Park\" title=\"Golden Gate Park\">Golden Gate Park</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Several of San Francisco's parks and nearly all of its beaches form part of the regional <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_National_Recreation_Area\" title=\"Golden Gate National Recreation Area\">Golden Gate National Recreation Area</a>, one of the most visited units of the <a href=\"/wiki/National_Park_Service\" title=\"National Park Service\">National Park system</a> in the United States with over 13&#160;million visitors a year. Among the GGNRA's attractions within the city are <a href=\"/wiki/Ocean_Beach_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Ocean Beach (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Ocean Beach</a>, which runs along the Pacific Ocean shoreline and is frequented by a vibrant <a href=\"/wiki/Surfing\" title=\"Surfing\">surfing</a> community, and <a href=\"/wiki/Baker_Beach\" title=\"Baker Beach\">Baker Beach</a>, which is located in a cove west of the Golden Gate and part of the <a href=\"/wiki/Presidio_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Presidio of San Francisco\">Presidio</a>, a former military base. Also within the Presidio is <a href=\"/wiki/Crissy_Field\" title=\"Crissy Field\">Crissy Field</a>, a former airfield that was restored to its natural <a href=\"/wiki/Salt_marsh\" title=\"Salt marsh\">salt marsh</a> <a href=\"/wiki/Ecosystem\" title=\"Ecosystem\">ecosystem</a>. The GGNRA also administers <a href=\"/wiki/Fort_Funston\" title=\"Fort Funston\">Fort Funston</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Lands_End,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Lands End, San Francisco\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Lands End</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Fort_Mason\" title=\"Fort Mason\">Fort Mason</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Alcatraz\" title=\"Alcatraz\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Alcatraz</a>. The National Park Service separately administers the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Maritime_National_Historical_Park\" title=\"San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park\">San Francisco Maritime National Historical Park</a> \u2013 a fleet of historic ships and waterfront property around <a href=\"/wiki/Aquatic_Park_Historic_District\" title=\"Aquatic Park Historic District\">Aquatic Park</a>.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Alamo_Square_with_Painted_Ladies,_SF,_CA,_jjron_26.03.2012.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Alamo_Square_with_Painted_Ladies%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_26.03.2012.jpg/220px-Alamo_Square_with_Painted_Ladies%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_26.03.2012.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"147\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Alamo_Square_with_Painted_Ladies%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_26.03.2012.jpg/330px-Alamo_Square_with_Painted_Ladies%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_26.03.2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/5d/Alamo_Square_with_Painted_Ladies%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_26.03.2012.jpg/440px-Alamo_Square_with_Painted_Ladies%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_26.03.2012.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"2507\" data-file-height=\"1671\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Alamo_Square_with_Painted_Ladies,_SF,_CA,_jjron_26.03.2012.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\n<a href=\"/wiki/Alamo_Square\" title=\"Alamo Square\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Alamo Square</a> is one of the most well known parks in the area, and is often a symbol of San Francisco for its popular location for film and pop culture.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>There are more than <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_parks_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of parks in San Francisco\">220 parks</a> maintained by the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Recreation_%26_Parks_Department\" title=\"San Francisco Recreation &amp; Parks Department\">San Francisco Recreation &amp; Parks Department</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-204\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-204\"><span>[</span>203<span>]</span></a></sup> The largest and best-known city park is <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_Park\" title=\"Golden Gate Park\">Golden Gate Park</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-205\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-205\"><span>[</span>204<span>]</span></a></sup> which stretches from the center of the city west to the Pacific Ocean. Once covered in native grasses and sand dunes, the park was conceived in the 1860s and was created by the extensive planting of thousands of non-native trees and plants. The large park is rich with cultural and natural attractions such as the <a href=\"/wiki/Conservatory_of_Flowers\" title=\"Conservatory of Flowers\">Conservatory of Flowers</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Japanese_tea_garden_at_Golden_Gate_Park\" title=\"Japanese tea garden at Golden Gate Park\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Japanese Tea Garden</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Botanical_Garden\" title=\"San Francisco Botanical Garden\">San Francisco Botanical Garden</a>. <a href=\"/wiki/Lake_Merced\" title=\"Lake Merced\">Lake Merced</a> is a fresh-water lake surrounded by parkland and near the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Zoo\" title=\"San Francisco Zoo\">San Francisco Zoo</a>, a city-owned park that houses more than 250 animal species, many of which are endangered.<sup id=\"cite_ref-206\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-206\"><span>[</span>205<span>]</span></a></sup> The only <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_California_state_parks\" title=\"List of California state parks\">park</a> managed by the <a href=\"/wiki/California_Department_of_Parks_and_Recreation\" title=\"California Department of Parks and Recreation\">California State Park</a> system located principally in San Francisco, <a href=\"/wiki/Candlestick_Point_State_Recreation_Area\" title=\"Candlestick Point State Recreation Area\">Candlestick Point</a> was the state's first urban recreation area.<sup id=\"cite_ref-207\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-207\"><span>[</span>206<span>]</span></a></sup></p>"},{"toclevel":1,"level":"2","line":"Law and government","number":"8","index":"16","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Law_and_government","id":16,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main articles: <a href=\"/wiki/Government_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Government of San Francisco\">Government of San Francisco</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Politics_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Politics of San Francisco\">Politics of San Francisco</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Mayor_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Mayor of San Francisco\">Mayors of San Francisco</a></div>\n<p>San Francisco\u2014officially known as the City and County of San Francisco\u2014is a <a href=\"/wiki/Consolidated_city-county\" title=\"Consolidated city-county\">consolidated city-county</a>, a status it has held since the 1856 secession of what is now <a href=\"/wiki/San_Mateo_County,_California\" title=\"San Mateo County, California\">San Mateo County</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-Coy_1919_409_21-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-Coy_1919_409-21\"><span>[</span>21<span>]</span></a></sup> It is the only such consolidation in California.<sup id=\"cite_ref-CityCounty_17-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-CityCounty-17\"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/Mayor_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Mayor of San Francisco\">mayor</a> is also the county executive, and the county <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Board_of_Supervisors\" title=\"San Francisco Board of Supervisors\">Board of Supervisors</a> acts as the <a href=\"/wiki/City_council\" title=\"City council\">city council</a>. The government of San Francisco is a <a href=\"/wiki/Charter_city\" title=\"Charter city\">charter city</a> and is constituted of two co-equal branches. The executive branch is headed by the mayor and includes other citywide elected and appointed officials as well as the civil service. The 11-member Board of Supervisors, the legislative branch, is headed by a president and is responsible for passing laws and budgets, though San Franciscans also make use of <a href=\"/wiki/Initiative\" title=\"Initiative\">direct ballot initiatives</a> to pass legislation.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SFCityHall.png\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/SFCityHall.png/220px-SFCityHall.png\" width=\"220\" height=\"143\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/SFCityHall.png/330px-SFCityHall.png 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/18/SFCityHall.png/440px-SFCityHall.png 2x\" data-file-width=\"1538\" data-file-height=\"1001\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SFCityHall.png\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\n<a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_City_Hall\" title=\"San Francisco City Hall\">San Francisco City Hall</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The members of the Board of Supervisors are elected as representatives of specific districts within the city.<sup id=\"cite_ref-SF_Gov_Supervisor_Districts_208-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SF_Gov_Supervisor_Districts-208\"><span>[</span>207<span>]</span></a></sup> Upon the death or resignation of mayor, the President of the Board of Supervisors becomes acting mayor until the full Board elects an interim replacement for the remainder of the term. In 1978, <a href=\"/wiki/Dianne_Feinstein\" title=\"Dianne Feinstein\">Dianne Feinstein</a> assumed the office following the assassination of <a href=\"/wiki/George_Moscone\" title=\"George Moscone\">George Moscone</a> and was later selected by the Board to finish the term. In 2011, <a href=\"/wiki/Edwin_M._Lee\" title=\"Edwin M. Lee\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Edwin M. Lee</a> was selected by the Board to finish the term of <a href=\"/wiki/Gavin_Newsom\" title=\"Gavin Newsom\">Gavin Newsom</a>, who resigned to take office as <a href=\"/wiki/Lieutenant_Governor_of_California\" title=\"Lieutenant Governor of California\">Lieutenant Governor of California</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-209\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-209\"><span>[</span>208<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>Because of its unique city-county status, local government exercises jurisdiction over property that would otherwise be located outside of its corporation limit. <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_International_Airport\" title=\"San Francisco International Airport\">San Francisco International Airport</a>, though located in <a href=\"/wiki/San_Mateo_County\" title=\"San Mateo County\" class=\"mw-redirect\">San Mateo County</a>, is owned and operated by the City and County of San Francisco. San Francisco also has a county jail complex located in San Mateo County, in an <a href=\"/wiki/Unincorporated_area\" title=\"Unincorporated area\">unincorporated area</a> adjacent to <a href=\"/wiki/San_Bruno,_California\" title=\"San Bruno, California\">San Bruno</a>. San Francisco was also granted a perpetual leasehold over the <a href=\"/wiki/Hetch_Hetchy_Valley\" title=\"Hetch Hetchy Valley\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Hetch Hetchy Valley</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Drainage_basin\" title=\"Drainage basin\">watershed</a> in <a href=\"/wiki/Yosemite_National_Park\" title=\"Yosemite National Park\">Yosemite National Park</a> by the <a href=\"/wiki/Raker_Act\" title=\"Raker Act\">Raker Act</a> in 1913.<sup id=\"cite_ref-CityCounty_17-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-CityCounty-17\"><span>[</span>17<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>San Francisco serves as the regional hub for many arms of the federal bureaucracy, including the <a href=\"/wiki/Ninth_Circuit_U.S._Court_of_Appeals\" title=\"Ninth Circuit U.S. Court of Appeals\" class=\"mw-redirect\">U.S. Court of Appeals</a>, the <a href=\"/wiki/Federal_Reserve_Bank_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Federal Reserve Bank of San Francisco\">Federal Reserve Bank</a>, and the <a href=\"/wiki/United_States_Mint\" title=\"United States Mint\">U.S. Mint</a>. Until <a href=\"/wiki/Base_Realignment_and_Closure\" title=\"Base Realignment and Closure\">decommissioning</a> in the early 1990s, the city had major military installations at the <a href=\"/wiki/Presidio_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Presidio of San Francisco\">Presidio</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Treasure_Island,_California\" title=\"Treasure Island, California\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Treasure Island</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Naval_Shipyard\" title=\"San Francisco Naval Shipyard\">Hunters Point</a>\u2014a legacy still reflected in the annual celebration of <a href=\"/wiki/Fleet_Week\" title=\"Fleet Week\">Fleet Week</a>. The State of California uses San Francisco as the home of the <a href=\"/wiki/Supreme_Court_of_California\" title=\"Supreme Court of California\">state supreme court</a> and other state agencies. Foreign governments maintain more than seventy consulates in San Francisco.<sup id=\"cite_ref-210\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-210\"><span>[</span>209<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>The municipal budget for fiscal year 2013\u201314 was $7.9&#160;billion.<sup id=\"cite_ref-211\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-211\"><span>[</span>210<span>]</span></a></sup> The city employs around 27,000 workers.<sup id=\"cite_ref-212\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-212\"><span>[</span>211<span>]</span></a></sup></p>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Crime and public safety","number":"8.1","index":"17","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Crime_and_public_safety","id":17,"text":"<p>The following table includes the number of incidents reported and the rate per 1,000 persons for each type of offense.</p>\n<table class=\"wikitable collapsible collapsed\">\n<tr>\n<th colspan=\"3\">Population and crime rates</th>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">Population<sup id=\"cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_213-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-213\"><span>[</span>212<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td colspan=\"2\">820,363</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">Violent crime<sup id=\"cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_213-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-213\"><span>[</span>212<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td>5,777</td>\n<td>7.04</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">&#160;&#160;Murder and nonnegligent manslaughter<sup id=\"cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_213-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-213\"><span>[</span>212<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td>69</td>\n<td>0.08</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">&#160;&#160;Forcible rape<sup id=\"cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_213-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-213\"><span>[</span>212<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td>108</td>\n<td>0.13</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">&#160;&#160;Robbery<sup id=\"cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_213-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-213\"><span>[</span>212<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td>3,484</td>\n<td>4.25</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">&#160;&#160;Aggravated assault<sup id=\"cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_213-5\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-213\"><span>[</span>212<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td>2,116</td>\n<td>2.58</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">Property crime<sup id=\"cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_213-6\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-213\"><span>[</span>212<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td>38,898</td>\n<td>47.42</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">&#160;&#160;Burglary<sup id=\"cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_213-7\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-213\"><span>[</span>212<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td>5,317</td>\n<td>6.48</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">&#160;&#160;Larceny-theft<sup id=\"cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_213-8\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-213\"><span>[</span>212<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td>28,242</td>\n<td>34.43</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">&#160;&#160;Motor vehicle theft<sup id=\"cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_213-9\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-213\"><span>[</span>212<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td>5,339</td>\n<td>6.51</td>\n</tr>\n<tr>\n<th scope=\"row\" style=\"text-align: left;\">Arson<sup id=\"cite_ref-FBI-UCR-T8_213-10\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-FBI-UCR-T8-213\"><span>[</span>212<span>]</span></a></sup></th>\n<td>207</td>\n<td>0.25</td>\n</tr>\n</table>\n<p>In 2011, 50 murders were reported, which is 6.1 per 100,000 people.<sup id=\"cite_ref-214\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-214\"><span>[</span>213<span>]</span></a></sup> There were about 134 rapes, 3,142 robberies, and about 2,139 assaults. There were about 4,469 burglaries, 25,100 thefts, and 4,210 motor vehicle thefts.<sup id=\"cite_ref-215\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-215\"><span>[</span>214<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/Tenderloin,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Tenderloin, San Francisco\">Tenderloin</a> area has the highest crime rate in San Francisco: 70% of the city's violent crimes, and around one-fourth of the city's murders, occur in this neighborhood. The Tenderloin also sees high rates of homelessness, drug abuse, gang violence, and prostitution.<sup id=\"cite_ref-216\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-216\"><span>[</span>215<span>]</span></a></sup> Another area with high crime rates is the <a href=\"/wiki/Bayview-Hunters_Point,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Bayview-Hunters Point, San Francisco\">Bayview-Hunters Point</a> area. Homelessness is also a growing problem in the city.<sup id=\"cite_ref-217\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-217\"><span>[</span>216<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>Several street gangs operate in the city, including <a href=\"/wiki/MS-13\" title=\"MS-13\">MS-13</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-218\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-218\"><span>[</span>217<span>]</span></a></sup> the <a href=\"/wiki/Sure%C3%B1os\" title=\"Sure\u00f1os\">Sure\u00f1os</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Norte%C3%B1os\" title=\"Norte\u00f1os\">Norte\u00f1os</a> in the Mission District,<sup id=\"cite_ref-219\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-219\"><span>[</span>218<span>]</span></a></sup> and to some extent the <a href=\"/wiki/Crips\" title=\"Crips\">Crips</a> in Bayview \u2013 Hunters-Point.<sup id=\"cite_ref-220\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-220\"><span>[</span>219<span>]</span></a></sup> There is a presence of Asian gangs in Chinatown. In 1977, an ongoing rivalry between two Chinese gangs led to a <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Dragon_massacre\" title=\"Golden Dragon massacre\">shooting attack at a restaurant in Chinatown</a>, which left 5 people dead and 11 wounded. None of the victims in this attack were gang members. Five members of the <a href=\"/wiki/Joe_Boys\" title=\"Joe Boys\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Joe Boys</a> gang were arrested and convicted of the crime.<sup id=\"cite_ref-221\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-221\"><span>[</span>220<span>]</span></a></sup> In 1990, a gang-related shooting killed one man and wounded six others outside a nightclub near Chinatown.<sup id=\"cite_ref-222\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-222\"><span>[</span>221<span>]</span></a></sup> In 1998, six teenagers were shot and wounded at the Chinese Playground; a 16-year-old boy was subsequently arrested.<sup id=\"cite_ref-223\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-223\"><span>[</span>222<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>The city is mainly patrolled by the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Police_Department\" title=\"San Francisco Police Department\">San Francisco Police Department</a>. The <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Sheriff%27s_Department\" title=\"San Francisco Sheriff's Department\">San Francisco Sheriff's Department</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/BART_Police\" title=\"BART Police\">BART Police</a> (public transit only), <a href=\"/wiki/Amtrak_Police\" title=\"Amtrak Police\">Amtrak Police</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/California_Highway_Patrol\" title=\"California Highway Patrol\">California Highway Patrol</a> and many other local, state, and federal agencies perform law enforcement tasks in the city.</p>\n<p>The <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Fire_Department\" title=\"San Francisco Fire Department\">San Francisco Fire Department</a> provides both fire suppression and emergency medical services to the city.</p>"},{"toclevel":1,"level":"2","line":"Education","number":"9","index":"18","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Education","id":18,"text":""},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Colleges and universities","number":"9.1","index":"19","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Colleges_and_universities","id":19,"text":"<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:172px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Lone_Mountain_Campus.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Lone_Mountain_Campus.jpg/170px-Lone_Mountain_Campus.jpg\" width=\"170\" height=\"227\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Lone_Mountain_Campus.jpg/255px-Lone_Mountain_Campus.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/5/59/Lone_Mountain_Campus.jpg/340px-Lone_Mountain_Campus.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"1944\" data-file-height=\"2592\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Lone_Mountain_Campus.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe Lone Mountain Campus of the <a href=\"/wiki/University_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"University of San Francisco\">University of San Francisco</a>.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<div class=\"hatnote boilerplate seealso\">See also: <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_colleges_and_universities_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of colleges and universities in San Francisco\">List of colleges and universities in San Francisco</a></div>\n<p>The <a href=\"/wiki/University_of_California,_San_Francisco\" title=\"University of California, San Francisco\">University of California, San Francisco</a> is the sole campus of the <a href=\"/wiki/University_of_California\" title=\"University of California\">University of California system</a> entirely dedicated to graduate education in health and biomedical sciences. It is ranked among the top-five medical schools in the United States<sup id=\"cite_ref-224\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-224\"><span>[</span>223<span>]</span></a></sup> and operates the <a href=\"/wiki/UCSF_Medical_Center\" title=\"UCSF Medical Center\">UCSF Medical Center</a>, which ranks among the top 15 hospitals in the country.<sup id=\"cite_ref-225\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-225\"><span>[</span>224<span>]</span></a></sup> UCSF is a major local employer, second in size only to the city and county government.<sup id=\"cite_ref-226\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-226\"><span>[</span>225<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-227\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-227\"><span>[</span>226<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-228\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-228\"><span>[</span>227<span>]</span></a></sup> A 43-acre (170,000&#160;m<sup>2</sup>) <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_Bay,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Mission Bay, San Francisco\">Mission Bay</a> campus was opened in 2003, complementing its original facility in <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_hills_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of hills in San Francisco\">Parnassus Heights</a>. It contains research space and facilities to foster biotechnology and life sciences entrepreneurship and will double the size of UCSF's research enterprise.<sup id=\"cite_ref-229\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-229\"><span>[</span>228<span>]</span></a></sup> All in all, UCSF operates 20 facilities across San Francisco.<sup id=\"cite_ref-230\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-230\"><span>[</span>229<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/University_of_California,_Hastings_College_of_the_Law\" title=\"University of California, Hastings College of the Law\">University of California, Hastings College of the Law</a>, founded in <a href=\"/wiki/Civic_Center,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Civic Center, San Francisco\">Civic Center</a> in 1878, is the oldest law school in California and claims more judges on the state bench than any other institution.<sup id=\"cite_ref-231\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-231\"><span>[</span>230<span>]</span></a></sup> San Francisco's two University of California institutions have recently formed an official affiliation in the UCSF/UC Hastings Consortium on Law, Science &amp; Health Policy.<sup id=\"cite_ref-232\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-232\"><span>[</span>231<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_State_University\" title=\"San Francisco State University\">San Francisco State University</a> is part of the <a href=\"/wiki/California_State_University\" title=\"California State University\">California State University</a> system and is located near <a href=\"/wiki/Lake_Merced\" title=\"Lake Merced\">Lake Merced</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-sfsu_233-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-sfsu-233\"><span>[</span>232<span>]</span></a></sup> The school has approximately 30,000 students and awards undergraduate, master's and doctoral degrees in more than 100 disciplines.<sup id=\"cite_ref-sfsu_233-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-sfsu-233\"><span>[</span>232<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/City_College_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"City College of San Francisco\">City College of San Francisco</a>, with its main facility in the Ingleside district, is one of the largest two-year <a href=\"/wiki/Community_college\" title=\"Community college\">community colleges</a> in the country. It has an enrollment of about 100,000 students and offers an extensive continuing education program.<sup id=\"cite_ref-234\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-234\"><span>[</span>233<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>Founded in 1855, the <a href=\"/wiki/University_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"University of San Francisco\">University of San Francisco</a>, a private <a href=\"/wiki/Society_of_Jesus\" title=\"Society of Jesus\">Jesuit</a> university located on <a href=\"/wiki/Lone_Mountain_(California)\" title=\"Lone Mountain (California)\">Lone Mountain</a>, is the oldest institution of higher education in San Francisco and one of the oldest universities established west of the Mississippi River.<sup id=\"cite_ref-235\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-235\"><span>[</span>234<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_University\" title=\"Golden Gate University\">Golden Gate University</a> is a private, nonsectarian, coeducational university formed in 1901 and located in the <a href=\"/wiki/Financial_District_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Financial District (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Financial District</a>. It is primarily a post-graduate institution focused on professional training in law and business, with smaller undergraduate programs linked to its graduate and professional schools.</p>\n<p>With an enrollment of 13,000 students, the <a href=\"/wiki/Academy_of_Art_University\" title=\"Academy of Art University\">Academy of Art University</a> is the largest institute of art and design in the nation.<sup id=\"cite_ref-236\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-236\"><span>[</span>235<span>]</span></a></sup> Founded in 1871, the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Art_Institute\" title=\"San Francisco Art Institute\">San Francisco Art Institute</a> is the oldest <a href=\"/wiki/Art_school\" title=\"Art school\">art school</a> west of the Mississippi.<sup id=\"cite_ref-237\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-237\"><span>[</span>236<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/California_College_of_the_Arts\" title=\"California College of the Arts\">California College of the Arts</a>, located north of <a href=\"/wiki/Potrero_Hill,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Potrero Hill, San Francisco\">Potrero Hill</a>, has programs in architecture, fine arts, design, and writing.<sup id=\"cite_ref-238\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-238\"><span>[</span>237<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Conservatory_of_Music\" title=\"San Francisco Conservatory of Music\">San Francisco Conservatory of Music</a>, the only independent <a href=\"/wiki/Music_school\" title=\"Music school\">music school</a> on the West Coast, grants degrees in orchestral instruments, chamber music, composition, and conducting. The <a href=\"/wiki/California_Culinary_Academy\" title=\"California Culinary Academy\">California Culinary Academy</a>, associated with the <a href=\"/wiki/Le_Cordon_Bleu\" title=\"Le Cordon Bleu\">Le Cordon Bleu</a> program, offers programs in the culinary arts, baking and pastry arts, and hospitality and restaurant management. <a href=\"/wiki/California_Institute_of_Integral_Studies\" title=\"California Institute of Integral Studies\">California Institute of Integral Studies</a>, founded in 1968, offers a variety of graduate programs in its Schools of Professional Psychology &amp; Health, and Consciousness and Transformation. Known for combining spirituality and social change, the Institute also features a bachelor's degree completion program.</p>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Primary and secondary schools","number":"9.2","index":"20","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Primary_and_secondary_schools","id":20,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote boilerplate seealso\">See also: <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_high_schools_in_California#San_Francisco_County\" title=\"List of high schools in California\">List of high schools in California \u00a7 San Francisco County</a></div>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Public_school_(government_funded)\" title=\"Public school (government funded)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Public schools</a> are run by the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Unified_School_District\" title=\"San Francisco Unified School District\">San Francisco Unified School District</a> as well as the State Board of Education for some charter schools. <a href=\"/wiki/Lowell_High_School_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Lowell High School (San Francisco)\">Lowell High School</a>, the oldest public high school in the U.S. west of the Mississippi,<sup id=\"cite_ref-239\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-239\"><span>[</span>238<span>]</span></a></sup> and the smaller <a href=\"/wiki/School_of_the_Arts_High_School_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"School of the Arts High School (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">School of the Arts High School</a> are two of San Francisco's <a href=\"/wiki/Magnet_school\" title=\"Magnet school\">magnet schools</a> at the secondary level. Just under 30% of the city's school-age population attends one of San Francisco's more than 100 <a href=\"/wiki/Private_school\" title=\"Private school\">private</a> or <a href=\"/wiki/Parochial_school\" title=\"Parochial school\">parochial schools</a>, compared to a 10% rate nationwide.<sup id=\"cite_ref-SFGPrvtSchools_240-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SFGPrvtSchools-240\"><span>[</span>239<span>]</span></a></sup> Nearly 40 of those schools are <a href=\"/wiki/Catholic_school\" title=\"Catholic school\">Catholic schools</a> managed by the <a href=\"/wiki/Roman_Catholic_Archdiocese_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Roman Catholic Archdiocese of San Francisco\">Archdiocese of San Francisco</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-241\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-241\"><span>[</span>240<span>]</span></a></sup></p>"},{"toclevel":1,"level":"2","line":"Media","number":"10","index":"21","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Media","id":21,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a href=\"/wiki/Media_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"Media in San Francisco\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Media in San Francisco</a></div>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SAN_FRANCISCO_CHRONICLE_BUILDING.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/SAN_FRANCISCO_CHRONICLE_BUILDING.jpg/220px-SAN_FRANCISCO_CHRONICLE_BUILDING.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"326\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/SAN_FRANCISCO_CHRONICLE_BUILDING.jpg/330px-SAN_FRANCISCO_CHRONICLE_BUILDING.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/1/13/SAN_FRANCISCO_CHRONICLE_BUILDING.jpg/440px-SAN_FRANCISCO_CHRONICLE_BUILDING.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"2055\" data-file-height=\"3042\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SAN_FRANCISCO_CHRONICLE_BUILDING.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nSan Francisco Chronicle Building</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The major daily newspaper in San Francisco is the <i><a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Chronicle\" title=\"San Francisco Chronicle\">San Francisco Chronicle</a></i>, which is currently Northern California's most widely circulated newspaper.<sup id=\"cite_ref-242\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-242\"><span>[</span>241<span>]</span></a></sup> The Chronicle is most famous for a former columnist, the late <a href=\"/wiki/Herb_Caen\" title=\"Herb Caen\">Herb Caen</a>, whose daily musings attracted critical acclaim and represented the \"voice of San Francisco\". The <i><a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Examiner\" title=\"San Francisco Examiner\" class=\"mw-redirect\">San Francisco Examiner</a></i>, once the cornerstone of <a href=\"/wiki/William_Randolph_Hearst\" title=\"William Randolph Hearst\">William Randolph Hearst</a>'s media empire and the home of <a href=\"/wiki/Ambrose_Bierce\" title=\"Ambrose Bierce\">Ambrose Bierce</a>, declined in circulation over the years and now takes the form of a free daily tabloid, under new ownership.<sup id=\"cite_ref-243\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-243\"><span>[</span>242<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-244\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-244\"><span>[</span>243<span>]</span></a></sup> <i><a href=\"/wiki/Sing_Tao_Daily\" title=\"Sing Tao Daily\">Sing Tao Daily</a></i> claims to be the largest of several Chinese language dailies that serve the Bay Area.<sup id=\"cite_ref-245\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-245\"><span>[</span>244<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Alternative_weekly\" title=\"Alternative weekly\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Alternative weekly</a> newspapers include the <i><a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay_Guardian\" title=\"San Francisco Bay Guardian\">San Francisco Bay Guardian</a></i> and <i><a href=\"/wiki/SF_Weekly\" title=\"SF Weekly\">SF&#160;Weekly</a></i>. <i><a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Magazine\" title=\"San Francisco Magazine\" class=\"mw-redirect\">San Francisco Magazine</a></i> and <i><a href=\"/wiki/7x7_(magazine)\" title=\"7x7 (magazine)\">7x7</a></i> are major glossy magazines about San Francisco. The national newsmagazine <i><a href=\"/wiki/Mother_Jones_(magazine)\" title=\"Mother Jones (magazine)\">Mother Jones</a></i> is also based in San Francisco.</p>\n<p>The San Francisco Bay Area is the sixth-largest <a href=\"/wiki/Designated_market_area\" title=\"Designated market area\" class=\"mw-redirect\">TV&#160;market</a><sup id=\"cite_ref-246\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-246\"><span>[</span>245<span>]</span></a></sup> and the fourth-largest <a href=\"/wiki/Designated_market_area\" title=\"Designated market area\" class=\"mw-redirect\">radio market</a><sup id=\"cite_ref-247\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-247\"><span>[</span>246<span>]</span></a></sup> in the U.S. The city's oldest radio station, <a href=\"/wiki/KCBS_(AM)\" title=\"KCBS (AM)\">KCBS (AM)</a>, began as an experimental station in San Jose in 1909, before the beginning of commercial broadcasting. <a href=\"/wiki/KALW\" title=\"KALW\">KALW</a> was the city's first FM radio station when it signed on the air in 1941. The city's first television station was <a href=\"/wiki/KPIX\" title=\"KPIX\" class=\"mw-redirect\">KPIX</a>, which began broadcasting in 1948.</p>\n<p>All major U.S. television networks have <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_television_stations_in_the_San_Francisco_Bay_Area\" title=\"List of television stations in the San Francisco Bay Area\">affiliates</a> serving the region, with most of them based in the city. <a href=\"/wiki/CNN\" title=\"CNN\">CNN</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/MSNBC\" title=\"MSNBC\">MSNBC</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/BBC\" title=\"BBC\">BBC</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Al_Jazeera_America\" title=\"Al Jazeera America\">Al Jazeera America</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/RT_(TV_network)\" title=\"RT (TV network)\">Russia Today</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/CCTV_America\" title=\"CCTV America\">CCTV America</a> also have regional news bureaus in San Francisco. <a href=\"/wiki/Bloomberg_West\" title=\"Bloomberg West\">Bloomberg West</a> was launched in 2011 from a studio on the Embarcadero. <a href=\"/wiki/ESPN\" title=\"ESPN\">ESPN</a> uses the local ABC studio for their broadcasting. The <a href=\"/wiki/Regional_sports_network\" title=\"Regional sports network\">regional sports network</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Comcast_SportsNet_Bay_Area\" title=\"Comcast SportsNet Bay Area\">Comcast SportsNet Bay Area</a> and it's sister station <a href=\"/wiki/Comcast_SportsNet_California\" title=\"Comcast SportsNet California\">Comcast SportsNet California</a>, are both located in San Francisco. The <a href=\"/wiki/Pac-12_Network\" title=\"Pac-12 Network\">Pac-12 Network</a> is also based in San Francisco.</p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Public_broadcasting\" title=\"Public broadcasting\">Public broadcasting</a> outlets include both a <a href=\"/wiki/KQED-TV\" title=\"KQED-TV\" class=\"mw-redirect\">television station</a> and a <a href=\"/wiki/KQED-FM\" title=\"KQED-FM\">radio station</a>, both broadcasting under the call letters KQED from a facility near the <a href=\"/wiki/Potrero_Hill,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Potrero Hill, San Francisco\">Potrero Hill</a> neighborhood. KQED-FM is the most-listened-to <a href=\"/wiki/National_Public_Radio\" title=\"National Public Radio\" class=\"mw-redirect\">National Public Radio</a> affiliate in the country.<sup id=\"cite_ref-248\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-248\"><span>[</span>247<span>]</span></a></sup> San Francisco\u2013based <a href=\"/wiki/CNET_Networks\" title=\"CNET Networks\" class=\"mw-redirect\">CNET</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Salon.com\" title=\"Salon.com\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Salon.com</a> pioneered the use of the Internet as a media outlet. Satellite channel non-commercial <a href=\"/wiki/Link_TV\" title=\"Link TV\">Link TV</a> was launched in 1999 from San Francisco.</p>\n<p>San Francisco inventors have made significant marks on modern media. In 1877 <a href=\"/wiki/Eadweard_Muybridge\" title=\"Eadweard Muybridge\">Eadweard Muybridge</a> pioneered work in photographic studies of motion and in motion-picture projection from. These were the first motion pictures. Then in 1927, <a href=\"/wiki/Philo_Farnsworth\" title=\"Philo Farnsworth\">Philo Farnsworth's</a> image dissector camera tube transmitted its first image. This was the first television.</p>"},{"toclevel":1,"level":"2","line":"Transportation","number":"11","index":"22","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Transportation","id":22,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote boilerplate seealso\">See also: <a href=\"/wiki/Transportation_in_the_San_Francisco_Bay_Area\" title=\"Transportation in the San Francisco Bay Area\">Transportation in the San Francisco Bay Area</a></div>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Freeways and roads","number":"11.1","index":"23","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Freeways_and_roads","id":23,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_streets_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of streets in San Francisco\">List of streets in San Francisco</a></div>\n<p>Due to its unique geography, and the <a href=\"/wiki/Freeway_and_expressway_revolts#San_Francisco\" title=\"Freeway and expressway revolts\" class=\"mw-redirect\">freeway revolts</a> of the late 1950s,<sup id=\"cite_ref-freeway_249-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-freeway-249\"><span>[</span>248<span>]</span></a></sup> San Francisco is one of the few American cities with <a href=\"/wiki/Arterial_thoroughfares\" title=\"Arterial thoroughfares\" class=\"mw-redirect\">arterial thoroughfares</a> instead of having numerous highways within the city.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:San_Francisco_Oakland_Bay_Bridge_at_night.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/San_Francisco_Oakland_Bay_Bridge_at_night.jpg/220px-San_Francisco_Oakland_Bay_Bridge_at_night.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"147\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/San_Francisco_Oakland_Bay_Bridge_at_night.jpg/330px-San_Francisco_Oakland_Bay_Bridge_at_night.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/95/San_Francisco_Oakland_Bay_Bridge_at_night.jpg/440px-San_Francisco_Oakland_Bay_Bridge_at_night.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"1200\" data-file-height=\"800\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:San_Francisco_Oakland_Bay_Bridge_at_night.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_%E2%80%93_Oakland_Bay_Bridge\" title=\"San Francisco \u2013 Oakland Bay Bridge\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Bay Bridge</a> offers the only direct automobile connection to the East Bay.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Interstate_80_in_California\" title=\"Interstate 80 in California\">Interstate 80</a> begins at the approach to the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_%E2%80%93_Oakland_Bay_Bridge\" title=\"San Francisco \u2013 Oakland Bay Bridge\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Bay Bridge</a> and is the only direct automobile link to the East Bay. <a href=\"/wiki/U.S._Route_101_in_California\" title=\"U.S. Route 101 in California\">U.S. Route 101</a> connects to the western terminus of Interstate 80 and provides access to the south of the city along San Francisco Bay toward <a href=\"/wiki/Silicon_Valley\" title=\"Silicon Valley\">Silicon Valley</a>. Northbound, the routing for U.S. 101 uses arterial streets <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_Street_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Mission Street (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Mission Street</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Van_Ness_Avenue_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Van Ness Avenue (San Francisco)\">Van Ness Avenue</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Lombard_Street_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Lombard Street (San Francisco)\">Lombard Street</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Richardson_Avenue_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Richardson Avenue (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Richardson Avenue</a>, and Doyle Drive to connect to the <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_Bridge\" title=\"Golden Gate Bridge\">Golden Gate Bridge</a>, the only direct automobile link to <a href=\"/wiki/Marin_County\" title=\"Marin County\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Marin County</a> and the North Bay.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Golden_Gate_Bridge_1926.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Golden_Gate_Bridge_1926.jpg/220px-Golden_Gate_Bridge_1926.jpg\" width=\"220\" height=\"165\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Golden_Gate_Bridge_1926.jpg/330px-Golden_Gate_Bridge_1926.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/e/ec/Golden_Gate_Bridge_1926.jpg/440px-Golden_Gate_Bridge_1926.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"2048\" data-file-height=\"1536\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:Golden_Gate_Bridge_1926.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_Bridge\" title=\"Golden Gate Bridge\">Golden Gate Bridge</a> is the only road connection to the North Bay.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/California_State_Route_1\" title=\"California State Route 1\">State Route 1</a> also enters San Francisco from the north via the Golden Gate Bridge, but turns south away from the routing of U.S. 101, first onto Park Presidio Blvd through Golden Gate Park, and then bisecting the west side of the city as the <a href=\"/wiki/19th_Avenue_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"19th Avenue (San Francisco)\">19th Avenue</a> arterial thoroughfare, joining with <a href=\"/wiki/Interstate_280_(California)\" title=\"Interstate 280 (California)\">Interstate 280</a> at the city's southern border. Interstate 280 continues this southerly routing along the central portion of the Peninsula south to <a href=\"/wiki/San_Jose,_California\" title=\"San Jose, California\">San Jose</a>. Interstate 280 also turns to the east along the southern edge of the city, terminating just south of the Bay Bridge in the <a href=\"/wiki/South_of_Market_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"South of Market (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">South of Market</a> neighborhood. After the 1989 <a href=\"/wiki/Loma_Prieta_Earthquake\" title=\"Loma Prieta Earthquake\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Loma Prieta Earthquake</a>, city leaders decided to demolish the <a href=\"/wiki/Embarcadero_Freeway\" title=\"Embarcadero Freeway\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Embarcadero Freeway</a> as well, and voters approved demolition of a portion of the <a href=\"/wiki/Central_Freeway\" title=\"Central Freeway\">Central Freeway</a>, converting them into street-level boulevards.<sup id=\"cite_ref-freeway_249-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-freeway-249\"><span>[</span>248<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/California_State_Route_35\" title=\"California State Route 35\">State Route 35</a>, which traverses the majority of the Peninsula along the ridge of the <a href=\"/wiki/Santa_Cruz_Mountains\" title=\"Santa Cruz Mountains\">Santa Cruz Mountains</a>, enters the city from the south as <a href=\"/wiki/Skyline_Boulevard\" title=\"Skyline Boulevard\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Skyline Boulevard</a>, following city streets until it terminates at its intersection with Highway 1. <a href=\"/wiki/California_State_Route_82\" title=\"California State Route 82\">State Route 82</a> enters San Francisco from the south as <a href=\"/wiki/Mission_Street\" title=\"Mission Street\">Mission Street</a>, following the path of the historic <a href=\"/wiki/El_Camino_Real_(California)\" title=\"El Camino Real (California)\">El Camino Real</a> and terminating shortly thereafter at its junction with 280. Major east\u2013west thoroughfares include <a href=\"/wiki/Geary_Boulevard\" title=\"Geary Boulevard\">Geary Boulevard</a>, the <a href=\"/wiki/List_of_streets_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of streets in San Francisco\">Lincoln Way</a>/<a href=\"/wiki/List_of_streets_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of streets in San Francisco\">Fell Street</a> corridor, and <a href=\"/wiki/Market_Street_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Market Street (San Francisco)\">Market Street</a>/<a href=\"/wiki/List_of_streets_in_San_Francisco\" title=\"List of streets in San Francisco\">Portola Drive</a>.</p>\n<p>The Western Terminus of the historic transcontinental <a href=\"/wiki/Lincoln_Highway\" title=\"Lincoln Highway\">Lincoln Highway</a>, the first road across America, is in San Francisco's <a href=\"/wiki/Lincoln_Park_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"Lincoln Park (San Francisco)\">Lincoln Park</a>.</p>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Public transportation","number":"11.2","index":"24","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Public_transportation","id":24,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Municipal_Railway\" title=\"San Francisco Municipal Railway\">San Francisco Municipal Railway</a></div>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:172px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:3_Cable_Car_on_Hyde_St_with_Alcatraz,_SF,_CA,_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/3_Cable_Car_on_Hyde_St_with_Alcatraz%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg/170px-3_Cable_Car_on_Hyde_St_with_Alcatraz%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg\" width=\"170\" height=\"273\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/3_Cable_Car_on_Hyde_St_with_Alcatraz%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg/255px-3_Cable_Car_on_Hyde_St_with_Alcatraz%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/92/3_Cable_Car_on_Hyde_St_with_Alcatraz%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg/340px-3_Cable_Car_on_Hyde_St_with_Alcatraz%2C_SF%2C_CA%2C_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg 2x\" data-file-width=\"1008\" data-file-height=\"1617\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:3_Cable_Car_on_Hyde_St_with_Alcatraz,_SF,_CA,_jjron_25.03.2012.jpg\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nA <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_cable_car_system\" title=\"San Francisco cable car system\">cable car</a> ascending Hyde St, with <a href=\"/wiki/Alcatraz\" title=\"Alcatraz\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Alcatraz</a> on the bay behind</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>32% of San Francisco residents use public transportation in daily commuting to work, ranking it first on the West Coast and third overall in the United States.<sup id=\"cite_ref-250\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-250\"><span>[</span>249<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Municipal_Railway\" title=\"San Francisco Municipal Railway\">San Francisco Municipal Railway</a>, known as Muni, is the primary public transit system of San Francisco. Muni is the seventh-largest transit system in the United States, with 210,848,310 rides in 2006.<sup id=\"cite_ref-251\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-251\"><span>[</span>250<span>]</span></a></sup> The system operates both a combined light rail and subway system, the <a href=\"/wiki/Muni_Metro\" title=\"Muni Metro\">Muni Metro</a>, and a large bus network.<sup id=\"cite_ref-transportation_252-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-transportation-252\"><span>[</span>251<span>]</span></a></sup> Additionally, it runs a <a href=\"/wiki/F_Market\" title=\"F Market\" class=\"mw-redirect\">historic streetcar line</a>, which runs on Market Street from <a href=\"/wiki/The_Castro\" title=\"The Castro\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Castro Street</a> to <a href=\"/wiki/Fisherman%27s_Wharf,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Fisherman's Wharf, San Francisco\">Fisherman's Wharf</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-transportation_252-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-transportation-252\"><span>[</span>251<span>]</span></a></sup> It also operates the famous <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_cable_car_system\" title=\"San Francisco cable car system\">cable cars</a>,<sup id=\"cite_ref-transportation_252-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-transportation-252\"><span>[</span>251<span>]</span></a></sup> which have been designated as a <a href=\"/wiki/National_Historic_Landmark\" title=\"National Historic Landmark\">National Historic Landmark</a> and are a major tourist attraction.<sup id=\"cite_ref-253\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-253\"><span>[</span>252<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Bay_Area_Rapid_Transit\" title=\"Bay Area Rapid Transit\">Bay Area Rapid Transit</a>, a regional Commuter Rail system, connects San Francisco with the <a href=\"/wiki/East_Bay_(San_Francisco_Bay_Area)\" title=\"East Bay (San Francisco Bay Area)\">East Bay</a> through the underwater <a href=\"/wiki/Transbay_Tube\" title=\"Transbay Tube\">Transbay Tube</a>. The line runs under Market Street to <a href=\"/wiki/Civic_Center,_San_Francisco\" title=\"Civic Center, San Francisco\">Civic Center</a> where it turns south to the Mission District, the southern part of the city, and through northern <a href=\"/wiki/San_Mateo_County,_California\" title=\"San Mateo County, California\">San Mateo County</a>, to the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_International_Airport\" title=\"San Francisco International Airport\">San Francisco International Airport</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Millbrae,_California\" title=\"Millbrae, California\">Millbrae</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-transportation_252-3\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-transportation-252\"><span>[</span>251<span>]</span></a></sup> Another Commuter Rail system, <a href=\"/wiki/Caltrain\" title=\"Caltrain\">Caltrain</a>, runs from San Francisco along the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Peninsula\" title=\"San Francisco Peninsula\">San Francisco Peninsula</a> to <a href=\"/wiki/San_Jose,_California\" title=\"San Jose, California\">San Jose</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-transportation_252-4\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-transportation-252\"><span>[</span>251<span>]</span></a></sup> Historically, trains operated by <a href=\"/wiki/Southern_Pacific_Lines\" title=\"Southern Pacific Lines\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Southern Pacific Lines</a> ran from San Francisco to <a href=\"/wiki/Los_Angeles\" title=\"Los Angeles\">Los Angeles</a>, via <a href=\"/wiki/Palo_Alto,_CA\" title=\"Palo Alto, CA\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Palo Alto</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/San_Jose,_California\" title=\"San Jose, California\">San Jose</a>.</p>\n<p>The <a href=\"/wiki/Transbay_Terminal\" title=\"Transbay Terminal\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Transbay Terminal</a> serves as the terminus for long-range bus service (such as <a href=\"/wiki/Greyhound_Lines\" title=\"Greyhound Lines\">Greyhound</a>) and as a hub for regional bus systems <a href=\"/wiki/AC_Transit\" title=\"AC Transit\">AC Transit</a> (<a href=\"/wiki/Alameda_County,_California\" title=\"Alameda County, California\">Alameda</a> &amp; <a href=\"/wiki/Contra_Costa_County,_California\" title=\"Contra Costa County, California\">Contra Costa</a> counties), <a href=\"/wiki/WestCAT\" title=\"WestCAT\">WestCAT</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/SamTrans\" title=\"SamTrans\">SamTrans</a> (<a href=\"/wiki/San_Mateo_County,_California\" title=\"San Mateo County, California\">San Mateo County</a>), and <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_Transit\" title=\"Golden Gate Transit\">Golden Gate Transit</a> (Marin and <a href=\"/wiki/Sonoma_County,_California\" title=\"Sonoma County, California\">Sonoma Counties</a>).<sup id=\"cite_ref-254\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-254\"><span>[</span>253<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Amtrak_California\" title=\"Amtrak California\">Amtrak California</a> <a href=\"/wiki/Thruway_Motorcoach\" title=\"Thruway Motorcoach\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Thruway Motorcoach</a> runs a shuttle bus from San Francisco to its <a href=\"/wiki/Emeryville_(Amtrak_station)\" title=\"Emeryville (Amtrak station)\">rail station</a> across the Bay in <a href=\"/wiki/Emeryville,_California\" title=\"Emeryville, California\">Emeryville</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-255\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-255\"><span>[</span>254<span>]</span></a></sup> Lines from <a href=\"/wiki/Emeryville_(Amtrak_station)\" title=\"Emeryville (Amtrak station)\">Emeryville Station</a> include the <a href=\"/wiki/Capitol_Corridor\" title=\"Capitol Corridor\">Capitol Corridor</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/San_Joaquin_(train)\" title=\"San Joaquin (train)\">San Joaquin</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/California_Zephyr\" title=\"California Zephyr\">California Zephyr</a>, and <a href=\"/wiki/Coast_Starlight\" title=\"Coast Starlight\">Coast Starlight</a>. Thruway service also runs south to <a href=\"/wiki/San_Luis_Obispo,_California\" title=\"San Luis Obispo, California\">San Luis Obispo, California</a> with connection to the <a href=\"/wiki/Pacific_Surfliner\" title=\"Pacific Surfliner\">Pacific Surfliner</a>.</p>\n<div class=\"thumb tleft\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:GGT_ferry_Del_Norte.JPG\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/GGT_ferry_Del_Norte.JPG/220px-GGT_ferry_Del_Norte.JPG\" width=\"220\" height=\"165\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/GGT_ferry_Del_Norte.JPG/330px-GGT_ferry_Del_Norte.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/9/9a/GGT_ferry_Del_Norte.JPG/440px-GGT_ferry_Del_Norte.JPG 2x\" data-file-width=\"2272\" data-file-height=\"1704\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:GGT_ferry_Del_Norte.JPG\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe Golden Gate Ferry <a href=\"/wiki/MV_Del_Norte\" title=\"MV Del Norte\">M/V <i>Del Norte</i></a> docked at the Ferry Building.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Megabus_(North_America)\" title=\"Megabus (North America)\">Megabus</a> recently relaunched intercity bus service in California and Nevada.<sup id=\"cite_ref-256\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-256\"><span>[</span>255<span>]</span></a></sup> San Francisco riders can chose from three routes (SF-San Jose-LA, SF-Oakland-LA, &amp; SF-Sacramento-Reno). The San Francisco stop is located in front of the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_4th_and_King_Street_Station\" title=\"San Francisco 4th and King Street Station\">Caltrain Station</a>. <a href=\"/wiki/BoltBus\" title=\"BoltBus\">BoltBus</a> began service between the Bay Area and Los Angeles in October 2013.<sup id=\"cite_ref-257\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-257\"><span>[</span>256<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay_Ferry\" title=\"San Francisco Bay Ferry\">San Francisco Bay Ferry</a> operates from the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Ferry_Building\" title=\"San Francisco Ferry Building\">Ferry Building</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Pier_39\" title=\"Pier 39\">Pier 39</a> to points in <a href=\"/wiki/Oakland,_California\" title=\"Oakland, California\">Oakland</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Alameda,_California\" title=\"Alameda, California\">Alameda</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/Bay_Farm_Island,_Alameda,_California\" title=\"Bay Farm Island, Alameda, California\">Bay Farm Island</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/South_San_Francisco,_California\" title=\"South San Francisco, California\">South San Francisco</a>, and north to <a href=\"/wiki/Vallejo,_California\" title=\"Vallejo, California\">Vallejo</a> in <a href=\"/wiki/Solano_County,_California\" title=\"Solano County, California\">Solano County</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-258\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-258\"><span>[</span>257<span>]</span></a></sup> The <a href=\"/wiki/Golden_Gate_Ferry\" title=\"Golden Gate Ferry\">Golden Gate Ferry</a> is the other ferry operator with service between San Francisco and <a href=\"/wiki/Marin_County\" title=\"Marin County\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Marin County</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-259\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-259\"><span>[</span>258<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Soltrans\" title=\"Soltrans\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Soltrans</a> runs supplemental bus service between the Ferry Building and Vallejo.</p>\n<p>Cycling is a popular mode of transportation in San Francisco. 75,000 residents commute by bicycle per day.<sup id=\"cite_ref-2011_Bicycle_Count_Report_260-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-2011_Bicycle_Count_Report-260\"><span>[</span>259<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>Pedestrian traffic is a major mode of transport. In 2011, <a href=\"/wiki/Walk_Score\" title=\"Walk Score\">Walk Score</a> ranked San Francisco the second-most walkable city in the United States.<sup id=\"cite_ref-261\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-261\"><span>[</span>260<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-262\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-262\"><span>[</span>261<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>San Francisco was an early adopter of <a href=\"/wiki/Carsharing\" title=\"Carsharing\">carsharing</a> in America. The non profit <a href=\"/wiki/City_Carshare\" title=\"City Carshare\" class=\"mw-redirect\">City Carshare</a> opened in 2001.<sup id=\"cite_ref-263\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-263\"><span>[</span>262<span>]</span></a></sup><sup id=\"cite_ref-264\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-264\"><span>[</span>263<span>]</span></a></sup> <a href=\"/wiki/Zipcar\" title=\"Zipcar\">Zipcar</a> closely followed.</p>\n<p><a href=\"/wiki/Bay_Area_Bike_Share\" title=\"Bay Area Bike Share\">Bay Area Bike Share</a> launched in August 2013 with 700 bikes in downtown San Francisco and selected cities south to San Jose. The <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Municipal_Transportation_Agency\" title=\"San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency\">San Francisco Municipal Transportation Agency</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Bay_Area_Air_Quality_Management_District\" title=\"Bay Area Air Quality Management District\">Bay Area Air Quality Management District</a> are responsible for the operation with management provided by <a href=\"/wiki/Alta_Bicycle_Share\" title=\"Alta Bicycle Share\">Alta Bicycle Share</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-265\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-265\"><span>[</span>264<span>]</span></a></sup> The system will be expanded in the future.</p>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Airports","number":"11.3","index":"25","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Airports","id":25,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_International_Airport\" title=\"San Francisco International Airport\">San Francisco International Airport</a></div>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SFOApril2005.JPG\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/SFOApril2005.JPG/220px-SFOApril2005.JPG\" width=\"220\" height=\"165\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/SFOApril2005.JPG/330px-SFOApril2005.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/3/3f/SFOApril2005.JPG/440px-SFOApril2005.JPG 2x\" data-file-width=\"1600\" data-file-height=\"1200\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:SFOApril2005.JPG\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nSan Francisco International Airport (Located in San Mateo County but operated by San Francisco) is the primary airport of San Francisco and the San Francisco Bay Area.</div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>Though located 13 miles (21&#160;km) south of downtown in unincorporated <a href=\"/wiki/San_Mateo_County,_California\" title=\"San Mateo County, California\">San Mateo County</a>, <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_International_Airport\" title=\"San Francisco International Airport\">San Francisco International Airport</a> (SFO) is under the jurisdiction of the City and County of San Francisco. SFO is a hub for <a href=\"/wiki/United_Airlines\" title=\"United Airlines\">United Airlines</a><sup id=\"cite_ref-UAL_266-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-UAL-266\"><span>[</span>265<span>]</span></a></sup> and <a href=\"/wiki/Virgin_America\" title=\"Virgin America\">Virgin America</a>.<sup id=\"cite_ref-VirginAmerica_267-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-VirginAmerica-267\"><span>[</span>266<span>]</span></a></sup> SFO is a major international gateway to Asia and Europe, with the largest international terminal in North America.<sup id=\"cite_ref-intlterminalfactsheet_268-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-intlterminalfactsheet-268\"><span>[</span>267<span>]</span></a></sup> In 2011, SFO was the 8th busiest airport in the U.S. and 22nd busiest in the world, handling over 40.9&#160;million passengers.<sup id=\"cite_ref-SFO-stats-2011_269-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SFO-stats-2011-269\"><span>[</span>268<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>Located across the bay, <a href=\"/wiki/Oakland_International_Airport\" title=\"Oakland International Airport\">Oakland International Airport</a> is a popular, low-cost alternative to SFO. Geographically, Oakland Airport is approximately the same distance from downtown San Francisco as SFO, but due to its location across <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Bay\" title=\"San Francisco Bay\">San Francisco Bay</a>, it is greater driving distance from San Francisco.</p>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Seaports","number":"11.4","index":"26","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Seaports","id":26,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a href=\"/wiki/Port_of_San_Francisco\" title=\"Port of San Francisco\">Port of San Francisco</a></div>\n<div class=\"thumb tright\">\n<div class=\"thumbinner\" style=\"width:222px;\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:FerryBuildingEmbarcaderoBayBridge.JPG\" class=\"image\"><img alt=\"\" src=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/FerryBuildingEmbarcaderoBayBridge.JPG/220px-FerryBuildingEmbarcaderoBayBridge.JPG\" width=\"220\" height=\"165\" class=\"thumbimage\" srcset=\"//upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/FerryBuildingEmbarcaderoBayBridge.JPG/330px-FerryBuildingEmbarcaderoBayBridge.JPG 1.5x, //upload.wikimedia.org/wikipedia/commons/thumb/4/4d/FerryBuildingEmbarcaderoBayBridge.JPG/440px-FerryBuildingEmbarcaderoBayBridge.JPG 2x\" data-file-width=\"2048\" data-file-height=\"1536\" /></a>\n<div class=\"thumbcaption\">\n<div class=\"magnify\"><a href=\"/wiki/File:FerryBuildingEmbarcaderoBayBridge.JPG\" class=\"internal\" title=\"Enlarge\"></a></div>\nThe <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Ferry_Building\" title=\"San Francisco Ferry Building\">Ferry Building</a> along the <a href=\"/wiki/The_Embarcadero_(San_Francisco)\" title=\"The Embarcadero (San Francisco)\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Embarcadero</a></div>\n</div>\n</div>\n<p>The Port of San Francisco was once the largest and busiest seaport on the West Coast. It featured rows of <a href=\"/wiki/Piers\" title=\"Piers\">piers</a> perpendicular to the shore, where cargo from the moored ships was handled by cranes and manual labor and transported to nearby warehouses. The port handled cargo to and from trans-Pacific and Atlantic destinations, and was the West Coast center of the <a href=\"/wiki/West_coast_lumber_trade\" title=\"West coast lumber trade\" class=\"mw-redirect\">lumber trade</a>. The <a href=\"/wiki/1934_West_Coast_Longshore_Strike\" title=\"1934 West Coast Longshore Strike\" class=\"mw-redirect\">1934 West Coast Longshore Strike</a>, an important episode in the history of the <a href=\"/wiki/Labor_unions_in_the_United_States\" title=\"Labor unions in the United States\">American labor movement</a>, brought most ports to a standstill. The advent of <a href=\"/wiki/Container_shipping\" title=\"Container shipping\" class=\"mw-redirect\">container shipping</a> made pier-based ports obsolete, and most commercial berths moved to the <a href=\"/wiki/Port_of_Oakland\" title=\"Port of Oakland\">Port of Oakland</a> and <a href=\"/wiki/Port_of_Richmond_(California)\" title=\"Port of Richmond (California)\">Port of Richmond</a>. A few active berths specializing in <a href=\"/wiki/Break_bulk_cargo\" title=\"Break bulk cargo\">break bulk cargo</a> remain alongside the <a href=\"/wiki/Islais_Creek\" title=\"Islais Creek\">Islais Creek</a> Channel.</p>\n<p>Many piers remained derelict for years until the demolition of the <a href=\"/wiki/Embarcadero_Freeway\" title=\"Embarcadero Freeway\" class=\"mw-redirect\">Embarcadero Freeway</a> reopened the downtown waterfront, allowing for redevelopment. The centerpiece of the port, the <a href=\"/wiki/San_Francisco_Ferry_Building\" title=\"San Francisco Ferry Building\">Ferry Building</a>, while still receiving commuter ferry traffic, has been restored and redeveloped as a gourmet marketplace. The port's other activities now focus on developing waterside assets to support recreation and tourism.</p>\n<p>The port currently uses Pier 35 to handle the 60\u201380 <a href=\"/wiki/Cruise_ship\" title=\"Cruise ship\">cruise ship</a> calls and 200,000 passengers that come to San Francisco.<sup id=\"cite_ref-270\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-270\"><span>[</span>269<span>]</span></a></sup> Itineraries from San Francisco usually include round trip cruises to Alaska and Mexico. The new James R. Herman Cruise Terminal Project at Pier 27 is scheduled to open 2014 as a replacement. The existing primary terminal at Pier 35 has neither the sufficient capacity to allow for the increasing length and passenger capacity of new cruise ships nor the amenities needed for an international cruise terminal.<sup id=\"cite_ref-271\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-271\"><span>[</span>270<span>]</span></a></sup></p>\n<p>On March 16, 2013, <a href=\"/wiki/Princess_Cruises\" title=\"Princess Cruises\">Princess Cruises</a> <i><a href=\"/wiki/Grand_Princess\" title=\"Grand Princess\">Grand Princess</a></i> became the first ship to home port in San Francisco year round. The ship offers cruises to Alaska, California Coasts, Hawaii, and Mexico. <i>Grand Princess</i> will be stationed in San Francisco until April 2014. Princess will also operate other ships during the summer of 2014, making it the only cruise line home porting year round in San Francisco.<sup id=\"cite_ref-272\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-272\"><span>[</span>271<span>]</span></a></sup></p>"},{"toclevel":2,"level":"3","line":"Safety","number":"11.5","index":"27","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Safety","id":27,"text":"<p>San Francisco has significantly higher rates of pedestrian and bicyclist traffic deaths than the USA on average. In 2013, 21 pedestrians were killed in vehicle collisions, the highest since 2001,<sup id=\"cite_ref-SF_Examiner_ped_safety_273-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SF_Examiner_ped_safety-273\"><span>[</span>272<span>]</span></a></sup> which is 2.5 deaths per 100,000 population \u2013 70% higher than the national average of 1.5 deaths per 100,000 population.<sup id=\"cite_ref-NHTSA_2012_Crashes_274-0\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-NHTSA_2012_Crashes-274\"><span>[</span>273<span>]</span></a></sup> Four bicyclists were killed in vehicle collisions in 2013,<sup id=\"cite_ref-SF_Examiner_ped_safety_273-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SF_Examiner_ped_safety-273\"><span>[</span>272<span>]</span></a></sup> a rate twice as high as the national average of 0.23 deaths per 100,000 population.<sup id=\"cite_ref-NHTSA_2012_Crashes_274-1\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-NHTSA_2012_Crashes-274\"><span>[</span>273<span>]</span></a></sup> On January 14, 2014, Supervisor <a href=\"/wiki/Jane_Kim\" title=\"Jane Kim\">Jane Kim</a> introduced Vision Zero, a proposal to eliminate all traffic fatalities in San Francisco by 2024.<sup id=\"cite_ref-SF_Examiner_ped_safety_273-2\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-SF_Examiner_ped_safety-273\"><span>[</span>272<span>]</span></a></sup></p>"},{"toclevel":1,"level":"2","line":"Notable people","number":"12","index":"28","fromtitle":"San_Francisco","anchor":"Notable_people","id":28,"text":"<div class=\"hatnote relarticle mainarticle\">Main article: <a in the <a href=\"/wiki/Sister_Cities_International\" title=\"Sister Cities International\">Sister Cities</a> program.<sup id=\"cite_ref-275\" class=\"reference\"><a href=\"#cite_note-275\"><span>[</span>274<span>]</span></a></sup> A total of 41 consulates general and 23 honorary consulates have offices in the San Francisco Bay Area.<sup id=\"cite_ref-276\"
